PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Tierney) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to provide for the autonomy of the Australian National University.
Motion (by Senator Tierney) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to table the explanatory memorandum and to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National University Act 1991 to ensure that the Council of the University is solely responsible for the application of money appropriated by the Parliament for the purposes of the University and for the management of the University.

The Australian National University is established by an Act of Parliament which specifies that there will be a research school in the field of medical science and that it is to be known as the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It also states that the Australian National University Council should have the entire control and management of the University.

Any attempt to actually separate these powers of management and control from the ANU Council would certainly be against the spirit of the Act. Any attempt to do this without the full knowledge of the Parliament is an attempt to circumvent the will of the Parliament.

Yet this is what the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has attempted to do. This Bill that I have introduced is structured to prevent this blatant abuse of Ministerial power.

Under the arrangements as intended by the ANU Act 1991, the Australian National University receives its funding from the Department of Education, Employment and Training and then distributes it accordingly. This preserves the autonomy of the University and the integrity of the John Curtin School of Medical Research, as was originally intended by the founders of the ANU.

Under the Baldwin plan, the John Curtin School will be singled out and funding responsibilities transferred to the Department of Health. Thus the Department will be able to determine the funding levels for the School, and will be able to influence the research profile of the School. The Department may very well decide that the School's activities should be wound down. Research in Australia has already suffered enough through the machinations of the Australian Research Council and the education profile process. Handing the funding for the John Curtin School over to the Department of Health is paving the way for even more centrally-determined research priorities. This stifles research, particularly that research in which the John Curtin School excels.

There needs to be a plurality of effort and funding in research. In this way money is provided for a variety of projects, including pure and applied research. This allows expansion into different fields that may produce a variety of benefits. Centrally-funded research leads to a blinkered vision of where research should be heading.

It is this invasion of the autonomy of a university that must be prevented. Government interference with and intervention in higher education institutions have been both disruptive and destructive. We now have a bureaucratically administered system dominated by ministerial discretion. Independence of the education system has had to make way for bureaucratic favours while the Government enforces policy with the threat of withholding funds. Now this ruinous policy has gone as far as threatening the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

The John Curtin School of Medical Research is a world class biomedical research institute. Its greatest strength is that it nurtures and tolerates long-term research on a diverse range of problems. It is one of the few institutions left that still continues this research—research which is not politically motivated but which ultimately yields the most beneficial results.

The John Curtin School of Medical Research is part of the Institute of Advanced Studies within the ANU. The Institute is an entity that consists of various research schools which interact with each other. It is that interaction that is very important. The burgeoning areas of science are the interdisciplinary areas. The interaction between the various research schools is therefore becoming increasingly important in joint projects. If these corporate ventures are to succeed then it is essential that the John Curtin School be a full corporate member of the Institute and not be separately funded.

The unique qualities of the John Curtin School should be treasured and nurtured. It is through institutions such as the School that Australia can stay at the cutting edge of scientific advancement. The John Curtin School was not established to be just another arm of government policy. This was clearly not the wish of its founders, who include such eminent Australians as Sir Howard Florey, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs. The latter two have objected strenuously and publicly to the proposed changes. The Government has tried to gain control of the School by circumventing the authority of the Parliament through manipulating the ANU into delegating its powers. This cannot be allowed.

The Minister's actions in relation to the John Curtin School of Medical Research have put all Australian universities on notice that the Federal Government will not hesitate to intervene at any level in their internal affairs. We cannot allow the Government to continue this interference in our higher education institutions. The Government has inflicted its policy on the ANU and the School against the wishes of almost all concerned. These actions must be rejected.

The Bill I present for the Senate's consideration today will ensure that funding for the John Curtin School, or for any other section of the University, stays under the control of the University. It will also ensure that the Minister is unable to abridge the autonomy of the University where it is provided for in the Act.

The John Curtin School of Medical Research must remain under the auspices of the ANU as has always been intended. Taking the responsibility for funding the School away from the University and giving it to the Department of Health will compromise its independence and detrimentally effect the world-class work being undertaken there.

This action by the Government will also set a worrying precedent for intervention in our other institutions of higher education. Once the Government feels that it can get away with this invasion of the autonomy of a university they could undermine other universities in a similar way, changing the education profiles of the various institutions. This would be detrimental to the development of the knowledge and expertise that will be essential if Australia is to have any future in a competitive internationalised world marketplace.

I urge all Senators to support the Bill to ensure that the standards of higher education in this country are not eroded any further than has already occurred under the Education "Dark Ages" of Dawkinisation—an era when bureaucracy has taken over and research has become more focused on short-term results. This action by the Government must be reversed and prevented from recurring. The addition of subsections (4) and (5) to section 42 of the Australian National University Act 1991 will have this effect.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report of the Australian Human Rights Delegation to China, led by Senator Schacht in July 1991, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in March 1992 in respect of the following specific matters:

TAB.TAB: (a)why the delegation was not provided with adequate information and briefing on the gross and continuing violations of human rights inherent in China's population control program which would have enabled the delegation:

(i)to challenge the assurances given to it by Chinese officials, and which it repeated in the report, that compulsory abortion and compulsory sterilisation are strictly proscribed and contrary to policy and that abortion is recommended only if contraception fails, but that abortion was never mandatory even in those cases, and
(ii)to avoid the credence the report gave to that alleged policy that abortion in China was never mandatory;

(b)whether the delegation at any stage was provided with a true copy of the family planning regulations for Sichuan province and whether its attention was drawn to the specific articles in those regulations which make it mandatory for particular women to submit to compulsory abortions and sterilisations and which make the unauthorised removal of an IUD an offence; and

(c)why the report failed to make reference to these provisions which legally entrench violations of human rights, whilst including certain articles from the same regulations for the purposes of setting out exemptions from one child per couple family planning regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, that part of the motion which relates to the first sitting day in March 1992 is inappropriate and, therefore, I may seek leave to amend the motion to state the first sitting day in May 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The issue to be referred is a very important issue, going to the integrity of the briefing of the delegation—not to the integrity of the delegation itself. Clearly, the ability of any delegation such as this to question Chinese officials about violations of human rights depends very largely upon the advice and briefings that it has been given.

The Committee should not take a great deal of time on the reference because it is clearly asked to do certain things; that is, to ask why the delegation was not provided with adequate information and briefing on the gross and continuing violations of human rights inherent in China's population control program which would have enabled the delegation to challenge the assurances which were given by the Chinese officials and which it repeated in the report.

I refer to page 47 of the report in which the assurances given to the delegation by the Chinese officials are repeated—that is, that compulsory abortion and compulsory sterilisation are strictly proscribed and contrary to policy; and that abortion is recommended only if contraception fails, but that abortion was never mandatory even in those cases. It should be remembered that this assurance was given by officials in the Sichuan province. I will show shortly that, in fact, the family planning regulations of the Sichuan province not only do not proscribe compulsory abortions but in certain circumstances and for certain women they prescribe—actually make compulsory—abortion.

The report also on pages 47 and 48 gives credence to the alleged policy that abortion is never mandatory. Clearly, that is not a fact and there is ample evidence to state that that is not a fact. The delegation, it appears, did have the Sichuan province family planning regulations. Annex 8 of the delegations's report quotes part of the Sichuan People's Congress regulations on Sichuan family planning. This was included for another purpose. But the delegation must have had the regulations. That being the case, why did it not ask the Chinese officials about certain articles of those very regulations which relate to coercion in matters of abortion and sterilisation? I will refer to some of those matters.

Article 13 states that couples who have inherited metal illness, mental deficiency, deformity or serious inherited diseases are forbidden to have children; and if pregnant, according to the regulations the pregnancy should be terminated. It is very noticeable that the eugenics program of the regime in China is nearing, if not surpassing, that of the Hitler regime. That must be of great concern to people in this chamber and, of course, to anyone who is interested in maintaining the universality of human rights.

Article 14 states that either husband or wife should adopt sterilisation measures after they have two children. Article 23 states that those who refuse education and give birth to children not covered by the plan will be fined from the month the child is born. Regarding pregnancy not covered by the plan, the article states that `both upon the husband and wife there will be imposed a fine of 20 to 31 a month during the period of pregnancy. If the pregnancy is terminated, the fine imposed will be returned'. Article 27 states that illegal removal of IUDs is prohibited. That is the Sichuan province regulation.

My motion goes on to ask the Committee to ask the delegation whether at any stage it was provided with a true copy of the family planning regulations for the Sichuan Province. Apparently the delegation had a copy, but presumably it was not a full and true copy, otherwise it would have been able to ask the Chinese officials about the regulations mandating abortion. The motion goes on to request the Committee to ask whether the attention of the delegation was drawn to the specific articles in those regulations which make it mandatory for particular women to submit to compulsory abortions and sterilisations and which make the unauthorised removal of an IUD an offence.

Finally, the motion requests the Committee to ascertain why the report failed to make reference to these provisions which legally entrench violations of human rights while including certain articles from the same regulations for the purpose of setting out exemptions for the one child per couple family planning regulations.

The Sichuan Province regulations are not isolated. It may be said that I am just quoting from regulations which are in force in the Sichuan Province and ignoring what occurs in other places. That is not the case. Let me suggest that it would be illuminating to find out what is in operation in other provinces. Just to give the Senate an example, I will deal with those regulations adopted for Henan in April 1990. We are not talking about 10 years ago; we are talking about current measures that are being enforced in China. Those regulations adopted for Henan in April 1990 leave little doubt as to their purpose. Here are a few of the provisions from articles 3, 4, 11, 22 and 24 which state:
Husbands and wives must carry out the duty of practising family planning.

To pursue family planning, we must persist in the practice of focusing our main efforts on propaganda and education. In the meantime, necessary measures must be adopted to strengthen management in accordance with law.

Childbirths must be placed under the guidance of the state and carried out in a planned way. The practice of each couple having one child only must be advocated and encouraged. Birth of a second child must be strictly controlled, and the birth of a third child must be prohibited.
Couples who have suffered from serious hereditary diseases including mental disease, hereditary mental incapability, hereditary deformity, and so on are strictly prohibited from having children. . .

. . . a woman of childbearing age who has had one child must use an IUD. If a couple of childbearing age have had two or more children, either the husband or the wife must be sterilised. . . . in case a woman becomes pregnant without permission under the state plan, remedial measures must be taken to terminate the pregnancy.

SPEECH.PARA: That clearly demonstrates the coercive measures contained in the law. I could cite further provinces. For example, in September 1991 Guangdong Province reported that its Vice-Governor had signed an emergency circular demanding that all areas push forward a full drive to promote the family planning then reaching its full climax. I quote from a transcript of Guangdong radio, the Guangdong Provincial Service:

By 20 September 1991, a total of 309,000 persons have undergone [one or another] of the four types of operations required by family planning [i.e., IUD insertion, vasectomy, tubal ligation and abortion], up 43 per cent over the same period last year.

The circular called on all localities to take effective measures to ensure that the task of subjecting the appropriate people to any one of the four kinds of operations for 1991 was fulfilled. It said that the climax should be maintained until the task is fulfilled, which should considerably increase the number of two-girl households who are willing to accept the ligation operation, and see to it that women who are about to have additional births have induced abortions.

That was broadcast on Guangdong radio on 24 September 1991, two weeks after the human rights delegation that went to China tabled its report in this Parliament. The Chinese family planning officials would be laughing at that part of the report that says that the delegation that went to China was assured that these sorts of violations of human rights did not occur.

PARA.TAB: I could go on for quite a long time about the history of the matter but I am trying to keep it short. Here we are with material that is right up to date. If the Senate Standing Committee is interested in this matter—and I am sure it is interested in the question of human rights—then these human rights violations should be examined.

I have just quoted from a circular issued by the Guangdong Province Vice-Governor in September 1991. I remind honourable senators of what was said: We should considerably increase the number of two-girl households who are willing to accept the ligation operation and see to it that women who are about to have additional births have induced abortions. Now, how do the Chinese go about that—leaving aside for the moment what is contained in the law?

The Chinese family planning cadres go about it in the most ruthless manner. Not only is there direct coercion, by measures that are described in a number of authoritative works, but also there are measures that are coercive in their effect.

Those direct measures, as I indicated, have been described on a number of occasions by authoritative persons, and also, of course, by the press. I note that on 11 September 1991, just two days after the China delegation gave its report to the Senate, there was an article in the London Independent titled `China's wanted children', and subtitled `They come for unborn babies in the dead of night'. This report was from a Chinese citizen who detailed the brutal population control attempts that take place in China.

I did mention that there are measures which are coercive in their effect and measures which leave little choice but for the women to submit to coercion. Those include penalising whole communities because of the birth of an unauthorised child or because a woman is pregnant with an unauthorised child—penalising workers for the same reason, with certain targets given for workplaces. No person, much less a person with a Labor background, should countenance that sort of anti-worker attitude. I think we are entitled to examine this further so that not only human rights are upheld and maintained but also the rights of individual workers.

To give an example of some of the measures which are coercive in their effects, heavy financial penalties are regularly imposed on individuals. They are forbidding penalties which push the couple even further into abject poverty. Whole groups and whole communities are affected by the penalties. For example, in September 1988 Liaoning Province instituted certain measures. In order to qualify for second births to daughter only families, villages had to meet six conditions, among which were the elimination of all unauthorised births, adoption of birth control by all women of child bearing age and the establishment of an effective system of population control. It was said that 80 per cent of Liaoning's villages were able to qualify but they could lose their eligibility at any time. If there are unplanned pregnancies, quotas for second births will not be issued to the village in question until remedial measures are adopted. If unplanned births are found, quotas for second births will be suspended for one year, starting with the month in question. Quotas will be re-issued only after effective adjustment. That means only after the individuals are coerced into having abortions, otherwise other families cannot have children. If that is not a measure with coercive effects, I do not know the meaning of the word `coercion'. Maybe there are attempts to redefine the meaning of the word `coercion' and the words `human rights'.

I believe passage of this motion is important so that we in the Senate are able to ascertain why there was not the appropriate briefing. I am not pointing the bone at the human rights section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade necessarily, although I believe it should have been its role to give adequate briefing. In this particular aspect of violations of human rights it seems to have given the matter over to certain sections of AIDAB, which sections have a vested interest in the diversion of Australian money into population control programs. I do not think that is an adequate way to deal with violations of human rights—that is another argument, of course; we can have that argument at any time.

It is important that we pass this motion not only for that reason but also because at some stage the people of China, who are suffering under this regime's dictatorial measures which violate their human rights, will rise up against their masters. They will be the ones, ultimately, who will be the leaders of China. They will be the ones who will recall what Australia did or did not do to protect their human rights when they were under threat, when those human rights were being trampled upon.

It is important for Australia that we look clearly at the facts. Where else can we look at them? I cannot think of any other way of doing it but to ensure that this motion is sent to the Committee so that information can be obtained from those responsible for briefing the delegation as to why certain things did not occur, why the whole truth was not available to the delegation before it went, why the questions were not asked of the appropriate officials in China, why the report simply mentioned the assurances of the Chinese officials, and why the report gave credence to the alleged policy that abortion in China is never mandatory when clearly the opposite is the case. There is an abundance of evidence from Chinese sources which shows that the opposite is the case.

I remind the Senate that the Chinese officials say one thing to representatives from the outside world but another thing to the people of China about this area of population control. I have a number of important up to date quotes, which times does not permit me to read now, from Chinese radio and Chinese press urging the population to accept control measures and threatening them with dire consequences if they do not. We know that these dire consequences result. I believe it is important, for the reasons I have just enumerated, that we refer this matter to the Committee for examination and report to the Senate. I hope the motion is carried.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! Senator Harradine, do you want to clarify the date for reporting? I understand that the Opposition is happy for 1 May to be the date. You started by suggesting that you would seek leave to alter the date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to alter the date to 1 May.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this reference going to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The principle that is referred to here, and to which Senator Harradine has referred a number of times in his half hour speech and at other times over recent years, is that it would be contrary to the views of every member of this Senate to see forced abortions as the practice in any country and for forced abortions to be enshrined in any regulation or law. The allegation is that this is not entirely clear and that this is a matter which could have been pursued by the delegation, which included three members of parliament, two from this chamber, that went to China in July last year.

PARA.TAB: Where the Opposition draws back from the wording of Senator Harradine's motion referring this matter to the Committee is in paragraph (a)—`why the delegation was not provided', which answers the question before the question is asked. We would rather have had words such as `whether the delegation was or was not provided', making it less prejudiced and less like the giving of an answer before the question is considered.

Similarly in paragraph (b) we draw back from the words `whether the delegation at any stage was provided with a true copy', which calls into question, some would read, the bona fides of the delegation, as if it were possible that our colleagues on this delegation from the Senate may have been given a true copy but did not disclose it in their report. Any such implication, I think, would be unintended by Senator Harradine but again, we do not accept any allegation of less than a bona fide approach by the members of the delegation that went from Australia to China in July 1991.

Paragraph (c) of Senator Harradine's motion refers to `provisions which legally entrench violations of human rights'. This calls into question whether China, nationally or in any of its provinces, including the province of Sichuan, has laws which `entrench violations of human rights'. I have visited Sichuan a number of times. I do not claim to be an expert on the law of Sichuan, but having heard Senator Harradine this last half hour, I still would be surprised if there were in the law of Sichuan province such an entrenching of a practice that violates human rights in the way that is espoused—that is, a law that required the abortion of a child. I would even ask whether the law was permissive in this matter. I sincerely doubt whether there is such an offence in the law of Sichuan.

Therefore, whilst the Opposition supports Senator Harradine's reference of this matter to the Committee, of which I happen to be the Deputy Chairman, on behalf of the Opposition I indicate that we draw back from some of the wording of the motion, in particular in the three instances that I have referred to.

Let me underline very clearly on behalf of the Opposition that we are opposed to forced abortion in any country at any time. It is as offensive to us as murder, rape or any other crimes that are recognised in this country as crimes and which are in most countries recognised as crimes. I believe that forced abortion is against the principles of human rights conventions agreed to in the United Nations to which Australia and many other countries are signatories. Certainly it would be triply offensive if such a practice were in any way sanctioned or enforced by any law of a province or state. It is my view that this is not the case in China. It may be a practice that is carried out unlawfully. It may even be a prevalent practice in certain provinces carried out unlawfully. I have certainly heard of such incidents. I have the same abhorrence of those incidents as I think every senator in this chamber would have.

I wish to refer to one other matter. In the conduct of this inquiry I see that the thrust is to ask representatives of the delegation what degree of information they may have received and why they did not receive fuller information about this matter. Another obvious witness would be a representative from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. We should ask why that Department did not take an initiative, or to what extent it did take an initiative, to brief the delegation prior to its departure from Australia. The inquiry into the delegation and the Department should be without prejudice; it should be seeking to know factually what information was available; and, regarding paragraph (c), should find out what the delegation found while it was in China—what evidence was sought, what evidence was discovered and whether it is in addition to anything that is in the report.

The reference does not actually envisage the Senate Committee conducting an inquiry involving China's Mission in Canberra or its Ambassador, or trying to ascertain from Australia what the situation may be in China. I am sure we would be assisted if the Chinese Ambassador wanted to put out a statement as to what the national law of China was, what the province of Sichuan's law was or what was practice, because these matters are referred to in this motion but I emphasise that the thrust of this inquiry is within Australia into the delegation, the Department and any other relevant body that could have informed the delegation.

While I was travelling back from Europe to Beijing in early October—just before I visited China for the third time in the last 15 months—I read very carefully the whole of the delegation's report. As the Senate knows, the delegation was led by Senator Schacht. Its deputy leader was my Liberal colleague Mr Connolly from the House of Representatives. Senator Bourne from the Australian Democrats and other academics and public officials from Australia were also part of the delegation. The delegation visited China in July 1991 and its report was made public by the Minister in, I think, September 1991. I am very grateful to those who got that to me in Moscow when I was coming back from representing this Parliament when visiting European parliamentary and government institutions. It was possible for me to read the report fully when travelling between Moscow and Beijing.

I happen to believe that it is a very useful report. It is one that I regard as having advanced Australia's concerns and advanced them in a way that they can be effective. We need to be sensitive to the culture and sovereignty of any country when we start to make statements about our concerns about that country's behaviour and practices. The offence to everyone in this chamber of the events of June 1989 with the deaths in and around Tiananmen Square was a matter that was obviously very much a part of this delegation's visit to China. Another matter was the concerns expressed for the full citizenship rights and human rights of the peoples of Tibet within China and of various outspoken political movements and representatives, including those with minority views in China.

In these three priority areas of discussion by the delegation with representatives of China a great deal of information was gained, a great deal of constructive discussion was undertaken, and the report has been a very useful one. When I went to China in October I was able to meet the Assistant Foreign Minister, Liu Huaqiu, the same man who on behalf of China opened the new and quite magnificent Chinese Embassy here in Canberra. I have met with Mr Liu Huaqui a number of times and the Australian Ambassador, Michael Lightowler, accompanied me in my discussions with him.

I mention one aspect only of our discussion and that is my reference to the human rights delegation of Australia and the report. The Minister agreed with me that it was a constructive visit and a constructive report and he welcomed a second visit. On behalf of the Government of China, he saw that it was an important part of the increasingly constructive relationship between Australia and China to progress this whole agenda with a second visit and possibly subsequent visits, and to build upon in a new way the work of the delegation in the first report.

I take this opportunity to encourage the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, to facilitate and to make arrangements for a second visit to China. It is with that in mind that this reference of a matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade by Senator Harradine can very constructively be undertaken by the Committee, fully taking into account any factual matters that Senator Harradine and others can bring before the Committee but without prejudice so that the second delegation can with more information and soundness clarify the remaining areas of issue.

I conclude by noting that whilst it was agreed that the date for reporting be 4 May—and I gave that date off the top of my head—the wording of the motion at the moment is: `report by the first sitting day in March'. I will be quite happy, as an alternative, that it be the first sitting day in May, which happens to be about 4 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that is what he did say.

—I would think that is what he said. We have to change only one word: `March' becomes `May'. As Senator McMullan heard something along those lines, I would be happy to do that, and it would achieve the same effect because we would report by 1 May. The Senate Committee at the moment is in the final stages of its inquiry into Australian's relations with Latin America. Senator Harradine envisages this being an inquiry that can be reasonably quickly undertaken and concluded. I agree with that. I therefore say, on the Opposition's behalf, that we support Senator Harradine's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody on the delegation—not one member of that delegation—is in favour of coercive abortion, just as I imagine that no Australian is in favour of coercive abortion ever, under any circumstances. I would be amazed if any person in this country was in favour of coercive abortion.

PARA.TAB: In part (a) of his motion, Senator Harradine wants to investigate why the delegation did not challenge assurances concerning abortion which were given to it by Chinese officials and why these assurances were repeated in the report. He is also concerned that the report gave credence to these assurances. I can assure Senator Harradine, as a member of that delegation, that the delegation continually challenged all assurances given to it by Chinese officials. We were not there to agree with what we were told by Chinese officials; we were there to question it and to try to find out what really was the case in many areas.

If Senator Harradine reads the report carefully he will discover that the three paragraphs which he finds offensive—in this 83-page report—all begin with qualifying statements such as, `The Delegation was told that. . . '. We were told these things. It does not say that we agreed that these things were the case. We said, `This policy . . . appeared to be confirmed . . . '. It appeared to be. We did not say, `It was confirmed'; we said that it appeared to be confirmed. We said, `The Delegation was assured that. . . '. The delegation was assured. That does not mean that the delegation agreed. We end with a qualifying statement to these three paragraphs, and that qualifying statement is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Delegation was unable to assess whether this was the case in practice.

If that is not enough for Senator Harradine and if he thinks that that gives credence to these things, I am sorry, it does not. That was not the impression that was meant to be given by this report and I do not believe that it is the impression that was given by this report. The delegation was very careful to qualify all statements it made on any subject in this report where we did not have any hard physical evidence.

PARA.TAB: In part (b) of the motion Senator Harradine asks:

SPEECH.PARA: whether the delegation at any stage was provided with a true copy of the family planning regulations for Sichuan province and whether attention was drawn to the specific articles in those regulations which make it mandatory for particular women to submit to compulsory abortions and sterilisations and which make the unauthorised removal of an IUD an offence;

I can tell Senator Harradine now that the delegation was given a copy of Sichuan Province family planning regulations. It is a 150-page document. It was in Chinese. We asked specifically for one small piece to be translated for us before we left the country, and that was the piece on the one-child policy, because we found that particularly interesting and it had a lot of information in it that we did not know beforehand; we had been given it in one briefing. We got that translated towards the end of our visit. We brought the 150-page document back. It is 150 pages; it has not all been translated. There is no reference in this report to us agreeing to what is in those regulations. There is one article in that 150-page set of regulations, article 13, which states that:

couples who have inherited mental illness, mental deficiency, deformity or serious inherited diseases are forbidden to have children. If pregnant, according to the regulation, the pregnancy should be terminated.

This is our English translation. The article means several different things in several different translations. Senator Harradine will understand that different translations mean different things. If we take the Bible, for example, it can mean completely different things depending on whether it has been translated by one person or another. It is the same with translation from other languages. The Chinese wording of this regulation is open to different interpretations, one of which could imply that abortion is mandatory in these circumstances. That is the only possible reference that we could find in these regulations to mandatory abortion.

PARA.TAB: Human rights in China is an absolutely massive subject. I am sure everyone will agree that Laogai, Laojiao, the situation in Tibet, torture, prison conditions, household registration, freedom of religion, capital punishment, freedom of assembly, counter-revolutionary crimes, party control, the court systems, the militia and the work of the People's Liberation Army are also important aspects of China's human rights framework and of Australia's relations with China in relation to human rights. If we start looking into everything that is in this report, undoubtedly there are details of these aspects to which no reference was made in the report. That will happen. It is only an 83-page report; we were there for three weeks. What the delegation attempted to provide in the report was an overview of the human rights situation in China, particularly in relation to formal and constitutional rights, the Chinese legal, judicial and penal systems, and how laws and policies are observed and implemented in practice, particularly in relation to the protection of the rights of individuals.

The Australian Democrats do not believe that the report even has the shortcomings described by Senator Harradine in his motion; nor are we convinced that the failure of the report to refer to one small section in a 150-page set of regulations from one of the provinces of China is sufficient reason to devote a great deal of the valuable time and effort of a Senate committee, and a large slab of taxpayers' money, to a Senate investigation.

I hope that I have convinced Senator Harradine; I am sorry if I have not. If the same delegation goes back to China, he is perfectly welcome to come to me or any other member of the delegation. If it does not, I am sure that he will be perfectly welcome to give any evidence he has to any future delegation members. It will be looked at the next time a delegation goes to China.

I honestly do not believe that this is sufficient reason to have a Senate investigation into this report which, if I say so myself, is a very good one. I do not believe that there is any reason to question whether the people on that delegation or from Foreign Affairs and Trade were properly briefed or whether we were given the right information before we left. A great deal of information was given to us before we left. It took all my spare time to read the information, which was mostly, I must admit, on the legal system, counter-revolutionary crimes, torture and the Universal Declaration on Human Rights. The Democrats will not be supporting this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to oppose this motion on behalf of the Government. I point out at the outset that the Australian Government does not support coercive or mandatory abortion.

PARA.TAB: The motion attempts to refer a matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. In fact, the matter relates to a report produced by a parliamentary and community delegation which visited China in July last year. I understand that several members of the Federal Parliament, including Senator Schacht and Senator Bourne, were in that delegation. I also understand that Mr David Connolly from the House of Representatives was the third parliamentary member of that delegation.

I point out that not one of those persons is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. They were all on that delegation in their capacities as members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I think I am correct in saying that all of them are members of the joint standing committee, which comprises members of this chamber and the House of Representatives, not the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

Basically, this motion proposes to refer for investigation a matter relating to the report of a joint standing committee to another committee. I find that a rather novel idea, particularly as the Committee to which the reference is intended to go has no expertise in this matter and none of the members of that Committee were members of the delegation. I certainly can say on behalf of myself and, I am sure, on behalf of other members of the Committee, with perhaps the exception of Senator Teague, that the members have not looked at the detailed content of the report on China of the human rights delegation, although we are certainly aware of the overview given by that report.

I can say that my Committee, like other Senate standing committees, has a very busy work schedule. It has an onerous work program. Of course, the committee members' time is valuable. We are already in March facing the 30 April deadline for our report on Australia's relationship with Latin America. This major inquiry which has been looking at our trade, transport, investment and cultural links with Latin America has been conducted by the Senate Standing Committee since last year. Over 100 written submissions have been received as evidence. Much evidence has been collected from around Australia. The inquiry has been characterised by path breaking evidence from the diplomatic community in Canberra. A number of ambassadors from the Latin American countries have come forward to give very important evidence to this Committee. That is quite an unprecedented step.

The deadline for the report of the Committee has already has been extended once. Originally the Committee was to report at an earlier date. That deadline was extended to 30 April by resolution of the Senate to enable the Committee to collect further important evidence, including evidence which will be forthcoming from the ambassadors for both Colombia and Peru. They will be appearing shortly before the Committee to help the Committee upgrade its evidence.

Since the Latin American inquiry was inaugurated, the Senate has referred an extra matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I refer to the resolution of the Senate passed as recently as 8 May last year which referred a further matter to the Committee for report; that is, the adequacy with which Australia's policy and guidelines for controlling military transfers safeguard Australia's defence, security and national relations.

So even though we have not yet completed our major report on Australia's trading and transport links with Latin America, another reference has been given to the Committee. I might point out that that inquiry has not yet begun; nothing has been done at this stage about that subsequent reference. Yet, here we are today debating a motion to give the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade another reference. Another reference is being proposed today although consideration of a reference referred to the Committee 10 months ago on 8 May 1991 has not even been commenced.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would be aware in your capacity as Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee, the Committee's members also have their own personal interests and priorities for inquiry. They have matters that they would like to look into. Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you have stated your view here this morning, but other members of the Committee have priorities for investigation. Some of my colleagues on the Committee regard it as a matter of urgency that we look into Australia's economic relationship with South East Asia. A number of members of the Committee have stressed as a priority that Australia really must look to upgrade its economic linkages in South East Asia to match the stronger political linkages that have been developed in recent decades. That is certainly a subject dear to the hearts of some members of my Committee.

In summary, I would point out that this Committee has a busy work program. It would not be easy to fit another reference, another inquiry, into the work program of the Committee. On that basis, I ask that the motion be rejected by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I can speak on behalf of a number of my National Party colleagues in congratulating Senator Harradine on his assiduous efforts in this regard. We also share very grave concerns about the substantive issues that he has raised. As has been said earlier by you, Mr Acting Deputy President, on behalf of the coalition, nobody on this side of the chamber is willing to tolerate forced abortions and conduct of a similar nature. I am very pleased that the coalition will be supporting the motion that Senator Harradine has moved today.

PARA.TAB: This matter is of major significance to our relationship with China. In particular, I note that when this delegation was first proposed and was given the imprimatur of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, it was intended that it would establish certain facts and form the basis for assessing the future direction of our relationship with China. If there has been a flaw in the briefings that the delegation was given prior to departing this country, or if they were of an unsatisfactory nature, then they are matters that it is right, fitting and proper for the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to inquire into.

I do not accept the argument brought before the chamber today by Senator Maguire that the Committee is very busy and that this matter is not of sufficient importance. A lot of Senate committees are very busy, but this matter is of importance. If the fundamental premises upon which this delegation left the country were flawed, then of course that bears major implications in connection with, firstly, the conduct of our relations with China and, secondly, the adequacy and the conduct of certain units within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. In saying that, I do not cast any aspersion upon that Department. I merely say that it is fitting, proper and appropriate for the Senate and for the Parliament to oversee the operations of government departments.

I am also very concerned, on behalf of the Chinese community in this country, that there is a proper and adequate understanding of our relationship with China. If there are flaws in the briefings that were provided to this delegation before it left, then obviously it means that the delegation would have been clearly unable to adequately fulfil the task which we asked it to perform, namely, to inquire into these alleged human rights violations in China.

I know that all of these matters are of grave concern to Australia's Chinese community for the very simple reason that for the Chinese community in this country family has a particular significance beyond a simple kinship arrangement, beyond the desire of individual parents to have children. Family is the basis of Chinese culture.

If it is shown that the briefings that were received by the delegation prior to leaving Australia were inadequate and that as a result certain matters relating to those very fundamental human rights, which every nation recognises, but most particularly to those cultural values which the Chinese community in this country still holds very dear, then I believe that the matter should be inquired into by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

It appeared today that Senator Bourne was a little upset in that she thought Senator Harradine was casting aspersions on members of the delegation. I know Senator Harradine very well and I know very well his motives for seeking this inquiry. I do not believe that Senator Harradine was casting aspersions on the delegation but merely saying that this matter is one of major significance. The proper conduct of the Department is a fitting area for the Senate Standing Committee to inquire into and, therefore, Senator Harradine has moved to refer this matter to the Committee.

These matters having been raised—and they are important matters of human rights to which this chamber should not just pay lip service but should pay due duty—it would be remiss of this chamber to now turn its back on the reference which Senator Harradine has moved today. To do so would give a clear signal to the rest of the world that we are not fair dinkum on international human rights. I would be gravely disappointed—it would be a slur on the integrity of this chamber—if this matter was not sent off even for one day's inquiry; that people's personal preferences for what they might like this Committee to do are more important than one day's inquiry into the adequate conduct of the briefings the delegation received and, moreover, human rights in China.

I believe wholeheartedly that this matter which has been moved by Senator Harradine today should be passed by this Senate for report back in the first sitting day of May. I have great pleasure in supporting Senator Harradine's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter. I have heard the views raised in this chamber on this issue by Senator Harradine, Senator Bourne and by my colleague Senator O'Chee. The issues raised are particularly important. It is important that we send groups from this Parliament overseas to look at issues such as human rights. The delegation which went to China attracted a lot of interest. The report of the delegation received great coverage in the media and elsewhere. Some issues have been raised here which are of some cause for concern.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the reports which are issued under the authority of this Parliament should be as comprehensive as possible. While I make no judgment as to whether the report under consideration, which was issued under the auspices of this Parliament, was as comprehensive as possible, I have had experience of reports issued by other bodies in this Parliament and it is of concern to me that, at least on one occasion—and I do not plan to canvass this at any length at all today—I believe that important information and evidence which was put before a particular committee was not properly canvassed in the report that was finally presented to the Parliament. Senator Schacht will know to which particular committee I refer.

I have much sympathy with the sort of views that have been put today, such as the suggestion to just investigate these matters. I believe, as Senator O'Chee said, that this does not have to be a witch hunt—and, of course, it will not—and that it does not have to go on for days and weeks; and, of course, it will not. However, I think it important that Parliament be assured that the report finally brought down is as comprehensive as it should be, and that the human rights issues are properly canvassed and the proper questions asked. I am happy to join with my colleague, Senator O'Chee, and other colleagues in supporting the motion which Senator Harradine has presented.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am disappointed by the fact that the Government, and at least one Democrat, is not going to support this motion. I would have thought that it was in the interests of finding out the truth that this matter go to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

PARA.TAB: Let me say first of all—and everyone around the chamber should know—that I did not draw into question the sincerity of any of those members of the delegation, either the parliamentary members or the non-parliamentary members. That is a red herring. I certainly did not do that and I do not do it now. As to the majority of the report, it was a useful document, as you said, Mr Deputy President. There are some other aspects of the document which, I believe, could have been improved upon but that is not the question that is being considered here.

Let me remind the Senate—and this has been said, I think, by Senator O'Chee and Senator Kemp—that this was a well heralded delegation. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) made much of the importance of this delegation and also stipulated that this question of the violation of human rights inherent in the population control program would be high on the agenda of this human rights delegation to China.

I am simply pointing out to the Senate the problems in the report of the delegation's undertaking the task of examining the violation of human rights in this area.Senator Bourne says that, yes, delegation members were provided with the Sichuan Province regulations but that they were provided in Chinese and were only part-translated before the delegation left for China. However, members knew before they went that they would be seeing family planning officials in China, in Sichuan province.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got them in China.

—The interjection here is that they got the regulations in China. Well, why were delegation members not given them here? Why were they not properly briefed on the subject in Australia so that the whole of the Sichuan Province regulations could have been translated.

PARA.TAB: I have had the translation for some time, and clearly that makes abortion and sterilisation mandatory. The delegation was unable to ask Chinese officials to back up their assurances. Senator Bourne says, `If you look at the paragraphs in the report, you will see that they are qualified'. There are phrases such as `The delegation raised allegations that compulsory abortion and compulsory sterilisation were used to enforce the one child policy'. The report said that the delegation was assured by Chinese officials that these practices `were strictly proscribed and contrary to policy'. If those concerned had the Sichuan Province regulations in Chinese, why did they not get the whole of those regulations translated into English so that they could have challenged that statement? They did not do so and they have just reported here to us that they were assured of these things by Chinese officials.

The report went on further to say that the policy towards abortion appeared to be confirmed. If they knew anything about the whole issue and the gross violations in the intimate lives of millions of Chinese, which those millions of Chinese are chafing about, they would have been able to ask the questions of the Chinese officials.

I have quoted from up to date sources, including internal radio and newspaper reports—reports that the people of China hear and read. They are quite different from the statements made by Chinese officials to foreigners. Let us make no mistake about it, there are systematic violations of human rights which the Chinese people are burdened with. They will rise up on some occasion and the people who have attempted to whitewash those violations of human rights will be targeted. The anger of the Chinese people will be vented upon them.

It is important for us all to realise, and particularly Senator Teague, who is the Chair of the Australia-China Parliamentary Friendship Group, that the current regime will not be there all the time, and the current ambassador who represents that regime will not be there all the time. It is important to know what exactly is going on in China. One will do so courteously, of course, but this must be done so that the facts are before us. To suggest that compulsory abortion and sterilisation are proscribed by law and are not policy is to indicate ignorance of what is occurring in China. I believe that this matter needs to be addressed and is vital and important not only to the Chinese but to the people of Australia.

I wish to deal with a couple of matters that were raised by Senator Teague, Senator Bourne and Senator Maguire in response to the motion. Senator Teague mentioned that the Opposition draws back from the wording of the motion. He appeared to suggest that the wording was a bit tough on the delegation. Well, I deliberately worded the motion so as not to imply anything in respect of the delegation. I assumed—I now realise that I assumed wrongly—that the delegation had not been given a copy of the Sichuan Province regulations, and particularly those regulations relating to compulsory abortion and sterilisation. I had assumed that because nothing was said in the report about it. The report did not say that in Sichuan Province the delegation members had challenged the family planning officials. Now we know that they did not get that part translated and therefore were not able to ask the question.

My assumption was wrong; I am sorry about that. Maybe that is a reflection of the fact that the delegation was not properly briefed before it left. That is what we are trying to get at. Who in the Department briefed the delegation and what did they brief it about in relation to this whole important area? It is all very well for Senator Bourne to say, `If you have all of the information, come along to me or somebody else who is going on a delegation and we will have a chat about it'. I want this out in the open. I think the people deserve to have it out in the open.

I know that there are attempts, particularly in AIDAB, to whitewash the population control program in China. I am surprised that the Government goes along with it. The Government is going along with that attempted whitewash, even though the program disgracefully violates human rights and workers' rights. The Government is going along with that whitewash and will not even allow the truth to come out through a Senate committee.

Senator Maguire says that one of the reasons the Government is not sending it off to the Committee is that it is invidious for the report of a joint committee to be vetted by a Senate committee. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the report was not from the Joint Standing Committee. Senator Maguire must know that, otherwise he does not know anything about the report. It was the report of a delegation to China, appointed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans. It was not from the Joint Committee at all. So Senator Maguire's argument for not referring it is specious.

I have been trying to get on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and I know that the Government wants to blackball me. I have had a great interest in human rights and foreign affairs from back in 1976—honourable senators can look at the speeches I made when I first dealt with areas of defence of this country—right up until the present time. I have also had a great interest in human rights. I know what is going on. I am sorry to see that Senator Schacht is not here to defend this report.

I think the time has come to put this to the test and to put the issue clearly before the Parliament. Australia provides moneys to the China population control program, indirectly and directly. Australia has provided ultrasound machines that are capable of determining the sex of the unborn—to see whether the unborn is a girl or a boy. The Senate should consider the missing females in China. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know that there is a vast amount of evidence to show that millions of females are missing in China. One of the obvious conclusions must be that girls are detected in pregnancy and then aborted, because of the desire of the Chinese to have a male offspring.

Are Australia's ultrasound machines being used for that purpose? These are the sorts of things that have not properly been examined and looked for. The Government is not even willing to have the matter considered in an atmosphere of seeking the truth in a Senate committee. Shame! The Government is going along with the whitewash that is being undertaken and paid for by AIDAB—the whitewash of the Chinese population control program, which imposes gross violations of human rights on the Chinese people. I ask that the Senate adopt this motion for reference of the report of the delegation to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

That the motion (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.
