DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY REFORM AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 March, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill has been introduced by the Government as its solution to problems within the construction industry in Australia. This solution is an absolutely classic example of the way this Government proposes to solve the problems of industry and of industrial relations within industry.

PARA.TAB: The Government's solutions and the approach that the Opposition takes in solving these problems are poles apart. I hope that in the course of this debate I will be able to indicate why the Opposition is opposed to the approach of the Government generally in relation to these questions and specifically in relation to this Bill, which, as I said, is the Government's solution to a particular problem in a particular industry.

It is because of that major gulf between the Government's proposal and that of the Opposition that we will be voting against the motion for the second reading of this Bill and we hope that we will thereby be able to succeed in defeating it and putting it aside.

As I have said, the Bill addresses the problems in the construction industry and proposes the Government's solution to them. That solution is being developed in the form of a national strategy for the construction industry which was first proposed by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in September 1990. The Bill gives administrative support and backing to an agreement that has been reached between the Federal Government, some State governments, leading industry organisations, and the Building Workers Industrial Union, which is the major representative of employees in the construction industry.

So this agreement to solve the problems of the industry has evolved with government blessing and government patronage and will now be backed by this legislation proposed by the Government. Through this legislation, the Government proposes to set up a construction industry development council which will be an advisory body. In other words, instead of having the consultations which have been going on between the industry, government and unions, a statutory body will be set up. If the consultations that have been going on have succeeded to the extent which the Government claims they have and that an in-principle agreement has been reached for major changes in the industry, one may ask why that process will be any better continued under statutory provision than by the method that has been developed up to date. But, of course, the Government has this extraordinary belief in the value of passing legislation through this Parliament as though that in itself will be the major solution to a problem. The Government seemed to justify its stance in the second reading speech where the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the industry considers that a strong and active role by government is an essential prerequisite to achieving substantial reforms in the industry.

This is clearly another example of the Government's longstanding policy of government leadership in developing solutions to industry problems. It harks back to its early days of `summitry' and so on. It has certainly been a theme throughout the life of this Government that it wants to have deals done between big government, big business and big unions, and that is the way it thinks all problems should be solved. As I have said, that is really the antithesis of the Opposition's solution to industry problems or economic problems.

PARA.TAB: As I said, an agreement has already been entered into for the strategy that is seen to be required to solve the problems of the industry. It is a strategy which is set out very fully by the Minister in his second reading speech. He refers in great detail to the in-principle agreement which is designed to improve the performance of the industry generally. The agreement is not simply designed to improve industrial relations—work practices and removing restrictive practices—but is also designed to improve the efficiency and the managerial competence of the industry. It does so through a whole series of points set out in the in-principle agreement referred to in the Minister's speech.

The Minister says that the Construction Industry Development Agency—although in the Bill it is called a reform agency, but that is to be amended—is to have the primary responsibility for ensuring that the parties adhere to the commitments in the agreement. But it is not apparent why it is necessary to have a statutory body for that purpose, unless it is thought that it will be better at spending money. Already, a good deal of money has been spent on this exercise and the Government is suggesting that a budget of another $10m will be appropriated for the agency to undertake this work the Government says is necessary for it to do.

Incidentally, the Government has already persuaded the Building Workers Industrial Union to contribute to the funds needed for this reform process. It has transferred the sum of $1.5m from the construction employees redundancy trust to the agency. There is already a major issue as to whether it is legal or proper to appropriate moneys which have been obtained for purposes of redundancy for workers in the industry to the agency. So the birth of this exercise that the Minister has started is highly controversial, for many reasons. This appropriation of money is another matter of controversy which will undoubtedly be raised in the courts.

As I said, the Opposition is concerned that we are now having these statutory bodies set up as part and parcel of this major industry reform exercise under the leadership of government. There are many, many problems in the construction industry and there have been for a long time. There have been a number of attempts to do something about them. We in the Opposition believe that the right steps have not been taken, and I will deal with that shortly. But let me say that this is not the first attempt to solve the problems of the industry.

I suppose the most notable attempt related to the moves which ultimately led to the deregistration of the BLF. That was seen to be one of the major reforms that was required in this industry and, ultimately, this Parliament took that step. But, associated with that step, were other non-statutory exercises which had been going on for some time in the wake of the deregistration of the BLF, whereby the Federal, Victorian and New South Wales governments particularly were endeavouring to get agreement on codes of practice in the industry. I understand that that process goes back to as long ago as 1986.

However, the deregistration of the BLF appears to have left the field pretty much to the Builders Workers Industrial Union and, although that union may have been a more moderate union than the BLF, that union itself has engaged in a great deal of union militancy of which the Opposition certainly would disapprove, and I think that in some respects probably the Government would also. To some extent, the BWIU has become a successor in title of the BLF. With the removal of the BLF, its position has, of course, been strengthened. As I said, in many respects it has taken over the role that was performed, although in a more militant way, by the BLF.

We should also note that we are dealing only with the construction industry. Although there has been a tendency to refer to this industry as `the building and construction industry', the legislation is certainly confined, and the in-principle agreement is confined, to the construction industry itself. That industry, which is a large one in itself—the Minister says it employs about 500,000 people—does not cover the whole of the building industry. We are talking about that part of the industry which puts up buildings in the central business districts and major shopping centres around Australia—and does the major industrial type building. Of course, a great deal of Australia's development is covered by this construction industry, and the particular union, the BWIU.

However, this whole strategy is being driven by that union on the one hand; and, on the employers' side, the major players are the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors and, to some extent but a lesser one, the Master Builders Association. There are also one or two other employer bodies that play subsidiary roles in this industry. But the legislation does not cover—and we are not discussing in this debate—what is known as the cottage industry, the building of houses and smaller constructions around the country. There is, indeed, a major difference between the structures of these two industries. The industry which is the subject of our debate here is certainly dominated by these big contractors and by this big union, the BWIU. It is with these players that the Government—and not only the Federal Government but also State governments—is in discussion and will become a partner, so to speak, in the solution of the problems of that particular industry, whereas the building industry, as it is probably more popularly thought of in Australia, that is, the industry that builds houses around the country, is a very different industry.

It is an industry which we think provides a much better pattern of industrial relations arrangements. That industry, the employers in that industry, rely particularly on the employment of subcontractors. The people who actually do the work are not employees and are not members of the BWIU—in many cases they are not members of any union. They are subcontractors and they make up a much more efficient industry than the construction industry that we are talking about.

As I said, it is acknowledged on all sides that that industry has had enormous problems. One of its major problems has been the pressures that have been brought to bear on employers by overly powerful unions—as I said, in the first place the BLF and now the BWIU. The industry has been characterised by the`no ticket, no start' principle, the closed shop—in effect, de facto compulsory unionism—which has been at the root of the problems. The problem has been the unions' power and methods. As I said, there has been on all sides agreement on the disruption caused by the BLF in the sense that this Parliament some time ago was prevailed upon to actually take the very strong step of itself, by legislation, deregistering that union. That was an unheard of thing for the Parliament to do, but the problems had become so horrific that it was clearly necessary.

However, there now seems to be some lessening of the tension between employers and employees to the extent that they believe that they can solve the problems of this industry by the methods set out in the Government's strategy and the legislation that is before us. It is with that that the Opposition disagrees. We believe that there are better ways of doing it.In search of other ways of solving the problem, the New South Wales Government several years ago set up a royal commission, presided over by Mr Roger Gyles, known as the Gyles Royal Commission. That Commission has been sitting for a considerable time now but has not yet reported. The report of that Royal Commission should be a major contribution to this debate in terms of deciding what would be the right way to go, but the Government has not waited for that. It has persisted with its own solutions to the problems and has come up with this legislation.

It seems fairly clear that this exercise is designed to pre-empt the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission into the industry. That in itself is a matter of concern, and we would certainly be a lot happier debating this subject after we had seen what the Gyles Royal Commission has come up with, rather than proceeding now in a way which clearly pre-empts the findings of that Commission.

As I have already indicated, the Opposition is concerned that this whole process is being driven by the large players in the construction industry. We are certainly also concerned that the whole agenda has been captured by the Building Workers Industrial Union and that the interests and methods of operation of that union will be entrenched.

We are also concerned that the approach of the Government—this big employer, big business, big union, big government solution; the in-principle agreement between the big players—is not the way to go. It threatens to transmit to all sections of the industry the standards that are being applied on construction sites in the big cities, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, to a large extent by militancy and muscle. Those practices will be transmitted throughout the whole of this industry. The efficient cottage building industry could even be threatened by these excessive standards.

It may well be that, by giving statutory force to this agency, the industry will tend to be closed to other than the major firms, whose practices will obviously be the preferred solution. Thereby, we will be locking out a whole range of small specialist contractors, skilled tradesmen and professionals who have played a major role in the past and who have been highly efficient. The whole industry in the future would then be characterised by solutions proposed by the big players. This would lead to the removal of a great deal of competition. As I have already said, we are very concerned about the effect that this whole process will have in terms of the adoption of the BWIU agenda.

I have given the reasons why the Opposition is opposed to this legislation and to the solutions put forward by the Government. Obviously we are not opposed to many of the attempts that have been made here to get better work practices, more efficiency, less confrontation and so on in the industry. Discussions of that kind are perfectly desirable; we are not opposed to them. However, we are opposed to confining this whole matter to the big players and then having their solutions adopted by this Parliament, with all the influence that that brings to bear.

There is certainly a lack of sanctions in the legislation. I am pleased to note that the Government is not proposing in any way to impose the usual legislative sanctions. The proposed agency will have a big budget. This agency will have the authority of the Government and this Parliament, and we believe that that will have very serious consequences on the future development of this very important industry.

I have already identified the most undesirable and dangerous elements of this legislation. The construction industry is a classic example of what happens when there are closed shops; when the no ticket, no start principle, which has been used by the powerful unions of this industry for so long, is allowed to continue. It is only when that most evil practice is eradicated from this system, and from industrial relations generally in this country, that there will be any real effective changes for the better in the construction industry.

The Opposition's policy is to eliminate compulsory unionism, be it de facto or by legislation. The term `preference to unionist' is used in Federal laws. Of course, we know that compulsory unionism has been legislated for in some States. But in this industry compulsory unionism was brought about by powerful unions such as the BLF and is now being continued by the BWIU. That is a fundamental problem in this industry and it has to be eradicated before any real solutions can be achieved.

We can have all the discussions, goodwill and agreements in the world, and we can have legislation of one sort or another, but none of it will be effective until this cancer in the whole of this industry—the no ticket, no start principle—is abolished. That will have to be done by legislation. Of course, it will be done by the Opposition on our return to government. I have put forward the principal objections of the Opposition to this legislation and set out our reasons why we intend to vote against it.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Bell, I note that the lights are dimmed in the Senate and that there is a storm in Canberra. I understand that lightning has put out the Telopea substation. Half the lights went out about 20 minutes ago, but I noticed that they did start to come back on when Senator Walters and Senator Tate came into the chamber and, of course, when Senator Durack was speaking. Although the sky is still overcast and the lights are flickering, we hope that the Senate will be back to full illumination very shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not sure what my role in that illumination will be. I found some of the matters raised by Senator Durack certainly interesting. Others might need to be challenged, or at least addressed by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook); that is his responsibility, not mine. I will confine myself to our reaction to the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1991 and the proposal to establish the Construction Industry Council, which I think is to be called the Construction Industry Development Agency.

PARA.TAB: The concept of a forum or peak council is one which has been demonstrated to have considerable advantages in other areas of our decision making process. I refer here to the Grain Council, Wool Council, Cattle Council and other peak advisory bodies and forums that we see throughout Australia. The danger is that, with the creation of such councils, there is the opportunity to create another level of either bureaucracy, or at least representation, which can stand between government and those who are having decisions made about them.

While that is a danger, I believe that there is the opportunity in this case to ensure that this body remains what it is intended to be, which is a forum for the discussion of those very problems about which Senator Durack was speaking. The very problems which beset our construction industry are problems which must be discussed. If a royal commission in New South Wales has been busy for some seven years without it reaching an outcome, it is obvious that those problems are of great consequence. With a facilitating development agency attached to the role of this forum and with that agency to cease operations on 1 July 1995, I can see that we are not entrenching a set of representations which will stand in the way, but rather something that will facilitate.

When I read the Bills Digest and was reminded that the Industry Commission's recommendations in its March 1991 report entitled Construction costs of major projects included that governments need to speed up reviews of regulations, standards and administrative procedures in order to reduce uncertainty and delays and to lower costs resulting from differences in standards and regulations, I thought to myself that this was being done. I harked back to my understanding that there was in existence an Australian uniform building regulations coordinating council and that there had been an intergovernmental agreement in about 1984. I was certain that there had been published a national building code for Australia and that all States had introduced at least the technical requirements of it. I checked up and contacted some people I knew who were involved in that process. I thought that this would have been a big part of that recommendation of the Industry Commission.

Before I came to this place I was in the construction industry and I worked closely with architects who were taking part in the introduction of the national specifications, which are virtually a standard system of specifying for buildings, on the architectural side of the construction industry. Having reminded myself of that, I realised that they were on the technical and design side and that this particular industry council is to be on the personnel, management and work practices side. Of course, I realised that the existence of the council would not exclude the process, which I knew of and which was already taking place. In fact, that process has now been developed and has received a considerable amount of support from within the construction industry.

In architecture in particular, the introduction of the Natspec system has replaced the previous inefficiencies that had a considerable reputation for adding to the cost of major buildings. I refer to the previous practices that applied at least in government buildings. For instance, where I once worked I saw them applied to a hose reel cover, which is a statutory requirement for a government building. It is a box that covers the fire hose. A draughtsperson was employed to come up with a design for it, to draw it up and to specify it.

A fence around a school shed, which had to be of a statutory height, required an initiative to be taken, a new drawing to be created and for it to be specified, all according to set standards, but every one had to be done afresh. Even the cubicles in school toilets were redrawn each time and re-specified for each new building. Of course, honourable senators would immediately agree that such a practice was ridiculously wasteful of time and even of materials. This was done even though all such components of buildings had to meet statutory regulations in terms of size, shape and description.

The Royal Australian Institute of Architects has been instrumental in encouraging its members to adopt the new Natspec system of standardised, nationally consistent specifications and their formulation and presentation as part of the architectural package. That has led to a great improvement in efficiency and consistency and it has made a technical contribution to reducing design costs in the construction industry. What I now note is that this Bill delivers to the Construction Industry Reform Agency the responsibility for achieving developments in the other areas of the construction industry.

It is important to note that one of the Industry Commission's recommendations said that governments could hasten labour market reform by insisting that more efficient labour and management practices were adopted on construction sites. It seems there is little we can do from this legislation, and from the particular angle of the Bill, to require that such practices be reformed. That will be the role, as I see it, of the agency itself after the forum of the Construction Industry Development Council has determined priorities. To me, that seems to be the appropriate way to go.

The Australian Democrats see it as a priority that that forum should assist with the development of energy efficient practices in building design. We do not have the opportunity here either to require that certain practices of management be adopted, or to require that certain practices of energy efficiency be adopted. But if enlightened advanced design is adopted, it is much easier to construct that in order to manage buildings so that they consume less energy. That would be apparent immediately to anybody who knew anything about the construction industry.

It is an area of great wastefulness, actually, and it is an area that is constantly developing as people—especially building owners and managers—recognise that, if efficiencies are sought at the input stage of design and construction, the cost of running a building can be reduced considerably. It is not just a question of turning the lights off—something which has occupied our minds here in this building in the last few minutes—but of energy efficiency itself. It is not just a question of turning the lights off when there is nobody in the building but it can also include such matters as the correct insulation of foundations. It can include intelligent, self-monitoring heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems. It can include strategies which are now almost mandatory, such as the optimum orientation of buildings towards or away from the sunlight, landscaping, tree shading et cetera. It can also include access to other buildings, airlocks and passageways. It can include waste incineration or disposal practices and it can include parking and orientation to traffic, and the orientation to other buildings in the area. These are the sorts of issues which the Australian Democrats believe can be profitably pursued within the Construction Industry Development Council forum. The opportunities are there. We believe that, correctly addressed, this could be a great facilitator of further efficiencies in our construction industry.

Senator Durack was right to identify the difference between the cottage building industry, often represented by the Housing Industry Association or the Master Builders Association, and the construction industry itself. I do not think it is right to extrapolate that the practices of the cottage building industry are relevant always to the construction industry, or vice versa. We should not assume that practices which may prove to be efficient in the construction industry will necessarily be carried over to the cottage industry. Such an assumption is misguided, and certainly defies the reality that exists in these industries. They are very different, as Senator Durack rightly observed. They are so different that I think it is quite wrong to assume that whatever is developed at this forum and implemented through this agency would actually be transferred and might threaten the cottage industry. That is wrong, and I have no fears that that will occur.

In supporting the general thrust of this Bill and what it proposes to achieve, the Democrats will move, in the committee stage, a small amendment which attaches to the Council the obligation to follow certain practices in the auditing stage. I will give more details about that in the committee stage, but I forewarn the Senate that that is what we intend to do.

I think that that adequately presents our position on this matter. As I said, if the issues raised by Senator Durack are to be addressed I believe it is the responsibility of the Minister and not the Australian Democrats to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1991 is yet another cosmetic gesture by this Labor Government to make it look as if it is really serious about industrial relations and structural reform. In fact, of course, it is nothing of the sort. The Government claims that the legislation relates to a broadly based strategy for the building industry, and that it will cover workplace reform, industry development and building regulation. This would be very commendable if it were workable and if there were not another hidden agenda.

PARA.TAB: In reality, the legislation is nothing more than a costly and extravagant attempt to foist the standards and practices of the Building Workers Industrial Union onto every building and construction site in Australia. It is an attempt to entrench the big players in the industry at the expense of the small and individual operators. The Government has pre-empted this Parliament—and, indeed, the debate on this legislation—and has already established on an interim basis the Construction Industry Reform Agency. The Agency board is made up of some of the most powerful and influential people in the building and construction industry.

The former Prime Minister announced in December that Mr Paul White, group construction director of the Concrete Constructions group, had been appointed as chairman of the Agency board. Most of the other board members are equally highly placed, being the chief executives or equivalent from Kinhill Engineers, Fletcher Construction Group, AMP Property Investments, Thiess Contractors, Hooker Cochram, the ACTU and the Building Workers Industrial Union.

The fact that all of this is already in place is yet another example of this Government's arrogance and contempt for this Parliament. It is asking the Parliament to rubber stamp legislation that is to all intents and purposes an established fact. It is more legislation by decree, as we have come to expect from this Government. This Senate should in no way be prepared to rubber stamp this legislation—or, indeed, any other piece of legislation. It is particularly so with regard to this legislation because it has been pushed through as an apparently innocuous Bill full of motherhood statements about industrial relations reform when in reality it will achieve nothing of the sort.

I understand from both industry and government sources that the Government and the Building Workers Industrial Union are, through this legislation, attempting to pre-empt the findings of the Greiner Government's Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales. I also understand that in reality the Building Workers Industrial Union has absolutely no intention of tackling the deep seated problems of the industry. Instead, it intends to make a few superficial reforms while at the same time ensuring that its own undesirable practices and standards are imposed at every level. For example, the industry maximum standards that have been achieved on construction sites in Sydney and Melbourne in relation to workers compensation, superannuation and redundancy payments would become applicable throughout the industry.

Only those firms which comply with these standards will be allowed to operate, thus virtually forcing small operators, specialist contractors and the skilled tradespeople out of the building and construction industry. It will extend the closed shop of the construction worker to include, in effect, the closed shop of the construction employer.

Despite the Government's claims that it has the support of the industry because the major players have signed the in-principle reform and development agreement, it is significant that several small industry organisations have refused to sign it or to participate in the Construction Industry Development Council.

One industry organisation says privately that it is only participating under duress and that it may have a better chance of control over the process by being part of it, rather than by being on the outside. This organisation also holds little hope that any real reform of industrial relations in the construction industry will be achieved through this legislation and the resulting structures.

The New South Wales Government has refused to participate and is leaving its options open. It is quite rightly waiting to hear the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission, which may very well come up with quite different recommendations from those of the organisation to be established by this legislation. As Senator Durack said earlier in this debate, the proper thing for this Government to do would be to wait for the findings and the recommendations of that Royal Commission before taking any action. In fact, as I said earlier, the real goal of this legislation is to pre-empt the findings of that Royal Commission because its findings maybe unpalatable to the BWIU and this Labor Government.

The New South Wales Government is well aware that there have been codes of conduct within the construction industry since 1986 and that these have been largely ineffective. It is not surprising that the New South Wales Government has strong reservations about this Federal reform strategy. Those reservations have also been echoed by the New South Wales Royal Commission.

The New South Wales Royal Commission has issued a discussion paper entitled Industrial Relations in The Building Industry: Historical Overview and Avenues for Change. That document contains a record of similar initiatives in industrial relations reform taken during the last decade. In its discussion paper the Commission has a long section on the decline of the so-called top down approach. This discussion illustrates how repeated attempts by government bodies, unions and employer groups to impose codes of practice on the building industry have consistently failed.

Referring to the blueprint for building industry development negotiated in 1988 between the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the Building Workers Industrial Union, and the ACTU, the paper says:

SPEECH.PARA: It was an example of people being obsessed with developing a new process as if the process itself once established, will automatically deliver some benefits.

For another good example of the failure of the top down approach, we need look no further than the accord and the centralised wages system that this Government continues to advocate. These two aspects of our industrial relations system consistently fail to recognise the needs and capacities of individual workers and individual enterprises, and they have been partly responsible for the massive level of unemployment in this country, currently standing at well over one million people.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps even more serious and damaging is the dubious legality of an extraordinary transfer of $1.5m from the Construction Employees Redundancy Trust to the Construction Industry Reform Agency being established by this legislation. The Gyles Royal Commission in New South Wales is currently investigating whether the trustees of the Construction Employees Redundancy Trust had the right to make this transfer of funds. The trust was set up as a charitable trust to meet redundancy payments to building workers. It is funded by contributions, mainly from small building contractors and sub-contractors at the rate of $40 per week, per employee.

According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 29 November last year, the Executive Director of the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Contractors Association sent a letter of complaint about the transfer of funds to the building Royal Commissioner, Mr Roger Gyles, QC. His reported response to that complaint makes it clear that he has very serious doubts about the legality of the transaction. He might very well have added a comment about the dubious morality of it as well.

As the Master Plumbers Association said, the transfer of funds was, and I quote, `Political and against the best interests of the plumbing industry'. The whole exercise smacks of similar attempts to reform the waterfront and the shipping industry, most of which have been all talk and very little action on the part of this Government or the unions, except for the spending of large sums of money on government inquiries and reports, and the setting up of reform authorities.

So far, in the construction industry, we have had a whole string of reports, recommendations, committees, in principle agreements and the like. Eighteen months and several million dollars later, all we have is a lot of talk, a larger bureaucracy and a commitment to spend a further $10.8m over the next three years.

The functions of the Construction Industry Reform Agency are spelled out in only very general and vague terms in this Bill. We have to turn to the recommendations of the Industrial Relations Working Party report to find the role and functions of the Agency in more detail. Ostensibly, the Bill aims to reform the construction industry and make it internationally competitive through what the Minister for Industrial Relations referred to as `real and tangible improvements in performance standards'. On the surface this looks like a good idea, and the Opposition certainly supports such a proposition. The trouble is that world-class competitiveness cannot be achieved in isolation. Unless the improvements are enacted in tandem with reforms across the whole spectrum of industrial relations, transport and the taxation system, they simply will not happen.

If this Government is really serious about reforming the construction industry, it should be looking positively at the coalition's Fightback package and our industrial relations policy as the blueprint on how to achieve real reform. It should not be trying to tear it apart by spurious and inaccurate analyses and claims with regard to Fightback!

For example, the Government's cynical move to entrench union power by the minimum membership requirement of 10,000 makes true enterprise bargaining absolutely impossible. The mega-unions created are unwieldy in size and are the very antithesis of enterprise bargaining unions, which this Government now belatedly claims to be championing. One simply cannot have genuine enterprise bargaining units when one has mega-unions in place. It is an absolute nonsense.

Seventy per cent of the construction industry is now covered by a new union called the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union, which has 96,000 members and is expected to grow to some 200,000 within 12 months. The union, the CFMEU—even the acronym is unwieldy—brings together the Building Workers Industrial Union, the Australian Timber Workers Union, the Allied Industries Union and the United Mineworkers Federation of Australia. One may well ask what interests they have in common in view of the various industries in which they work. A number of quite unrelated industries there are being combined into the one union.

Two more unions, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association—again one may question the relevance to the building industry—and the Operative Plasterers and Plaster Workers Federation, which certainly does have a closer relationship, are due to vote soon on amalgamating with it.

The Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union has said that it has the potential to expand its membership to more than 300,000. A union of that size cannot possibly look after the individual needs of its members and it cannot possibly have the flexibility needed to cope with individual workplace needs and demands.

This Government may claim that it wants enterprise bargaining, but in reality it is simply mouthing platitudes. It has no genuine commitment to genuine enterprise bargaining. If it were really serious it would not tolerate allowing union power to be concentrated in the hands of so few. The reality is that you can only have genuine enterprise bargaining if you have voluntary unionism in place and if you have a requirement that no third parties be involved in those negotiations except at the behest of the employees involved.

These amalgamations are not sitting easily with all of the unions involved, either. There are already tensions arising between the different interests of employers and rival unions. There is a struggle going on for control of the construction industry, between the Building Workers Industrial Union and the Federation of Industrial, Manufacturing and Engineering Employees. The Industrial Relations Commission is due to start hearing a dispute between the two very soon.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also an ongoing power struggle between the Australian Workers Union and the Building Workers Industrial Union over who will have control of the construction and building industry.

PARA.TAB: One of the claims that is often made for these mega-unions is that they will remove demarcation difficulties. Yet here we have a struggle going on between the unions themselves for power, for membership and for control of various sectors of the work force—obviously a problem with demarcation. Now that the BWIU has amalgamated with the United Mineworkers Federation of Australia, we also have a struggle going on over which union will control the mining industry.

Last week the Australian Workers Union lodged an application with the Industrial Relations Commission to exclude the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association from the metalliferous mining industry. None of this points to a smooth passage of reform for the construction industry. Indeed, quite the opposite: a bigger union representing construction industry workers is not going to stamp out the rampant work rorts so prevalent on construction sites and elsewhere. It is not going to assist the abolition of the closed shop, the `no ticket, no start' regime that operates to the detriment of Australia in industry right across the country.

We will not have true reform of the construction industry—or of any other industry for that matter—until compulsory unionism is abolished and workers can choose whether they want to belong to a union. If they choose to belong to a union, they must have an open choice as to which particular union they join. The coalition will not support the establishment of a bureaucratic process using the top down approach, which only entrenches the power of the big players in this industry and the Building Workers Industrial Union, which has the capacity to hold the industry to ransom, and which will exclude the smaller operators.

The coalition does support the professed aims of the reform strategy, but we will not support a process which ignores the realities of true enterprise bargaining, as I spelt out a few moments ago, and which will force all employers to adhere to a national code of payment and work practices regardless of their individual circumstances. We will not condone the establishment of yet another bureaucracy, and the spending of almost $11m of taxpayers' money, which will benefit no-one except the Building Workers Industrial Union and the major construction companies. We will not support a process which quite clearly does not have the support of a large part of the industry it claims to be reforming. For all of those reasons, it is obvious that the Opposition will not support this legislation. I urge the Senate generally likewise to oppose its passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me read from the Prime Minister's statement last Tuesday. In the industrial relations section he said:

PARA.TAB: Modern industry has to be a co-operative process.

That is a truth we tapped when we began the task of changing our industrial culture, from one in which employers and workers are always at each other's throats, to one where they talk about how to do things better.
We will continue this change and move quickly towards a bargaining system in which higher wages will come from increased efficiency.
Employers and workers will be free to change workplaces in whichever way is most efficient, and to register their settlements as binding agreements with the Industrial Relations Commission.
But basic standards must be met. We will not support slashing minimum wages and conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: That all sounds wonderful. Indeed, it seems at first glance that the Government has pinched our industrial relations policy. But when one goes into it, one finds that behind the rhetoric there are very basic differences. It is far from our planned reforms.

Those 68 per cent of private sector workers who do not belong to unions and who prefer to negotiate with their employer directly will be able to do so, bearing in mind that they cannot negotiate below a minimum wage. That is one basic difference.

The next very basic difference is that we believe in voluntary unionism. Voluntary unionism is one of the very basic tenets of democracy. As you would be well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have spoken in this place many times about the Australian Labor Party's special brand of democracy—a very special brand that suits its particular thoughts on democracy. I spoke last time about that special brand of Labor democracy when we were talking about political advertising and the right of some people to indulge in free time political advertising which does not extend to everyone who wants to stand for politics. The boycott has been applied by member states of the Arab League, with varying degrees of intensity for some 40 years, to limit international trade relations with Israel. The existence of the boycott, quite apart from its inherent obnoxiousness, is obviously detrimental to promoting an atmosphere conducive to finding a solution to the Arab-Israel conflict. Several times I have urged Arab governments to dismantle the boycott as a gesture of goodwill, which I would expect Israel to reciprocate in other ways.

PARA.TAB: Last year the Zionist Federation of Australia presented me with a very detailed submission urging the enactment of Australian legislation similar to United States legislation which does outlaw compliance with the boycott. The submission also pointed out that some Australian chambers of commerce were effectively complying with the boycott by issuing certificates of origin, apparently with government authority, overstamped with the printed assertion that the goods in question had no association with Israel.

While I am not yet quite persuaded that legislation on this subject is appropriate, I have decided to keep under active review that possibility. More specifically, and more immediately, in relation to certificates of origin, I have now written to umbrella associations of chambers of commerce reminding them that no chambers have Australian Government authorisation and have never had such authorisation for overstamping certificates of origin with statements that effectively comply with the boycott and that they certainly should not claim, expressly or impliedly, such authority.

I have also directed my Department to remind all government departments concerned with the boycott of Australian Government guidelines on dealing with boycott offices. These guidelines stress that any approach to boycott offices should be made only on clearance or instructions from Canberra and that where direct contact is unavoidable in order, for example, to clear up some factual error in its application to some particular company this should be done orally and in as low key a manner as practicable. Moreover, official Australian contacts with the boycott offices, to the extent that they are ever necessary, will always be made in circumstances in the future which make absolutely clear that Australia opposes the boycott and that contacts with boycott offices to assist Australian companies do not imply in any way tacit acceptance of the boycott.

—Mr President, Senator Crichton-Browne was kind enough to give me some notice of his question just before Question Time—I assume because he actually wanted some information rather than to score a point.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: It is an important question, and I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for giving me notice of it. The Canadian Anti-Doping Organisation tested Mr Vinnicombe on 25 May 1991 in accordance with the International Olympic Committee's anti-doping charter. Mr Vinnicombe's A sample tested positive for anabolic steroids. Before the B sample was tested, Mr Vinnicombe sought to change his amateur status by seeking a professional licence. The B sample was subsequently tested and it was confirmed positive for anabolic steroids on 13 June 1991.

With regard to the question of the APCC's legal costs, the Government has not at this point been approached for assistance with any such costs and so the question has not currently arisen. A request of this nature would be considered, if it is received, on its merits.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Can the Minister inform the Senate of Australia's position regarding protection of endangered animals, in light of the article in last Sunday's Melbourne Age which said that the Bush Administration in the United States was sympathetic to a relaxation of protection and to open international trading in elephant products, which is being discussed this week in Japan at the meeting of the UN Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, which is normally known as CITES?

—This is an extremely important issue for a species that is well and truly endangered at this time. In 1989, Australia placed the African elephant on schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Regulation of Imports and Exports Act 1982 prior to the species being listed on appendix 1, effectively prohibiting the import of ivory, except for antique ivory, into Australia.

PARA.TAB: Several southern African countries have submitted proposals to transfer their elephant populations to appendix 2. Such proposals are controversial and potentially divisive and are being examined by a panel of experts that have been established for this purpose.

Australia actively supported the 1989 listing of the African elephant on appendix 1. The Government remains firmly opposed to the resumption of trade in ivory or other elephant products. The Minister has directed the Australian delegation to maintain Australia's firm opposition to down-listing of the African elephant. Regardless of the outcome of the meeting, Australia will maintain its right, under article 14 of the convention, to adopt stricter measures and to retain our own import ban on elephant ivory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This debate is on the Notice Paper for a later hour this day. I therefore suggest that under the Standing Orders it is inappropriate that this question be asked and answered at this time.

—Mr President, the answer directly relates to it because it is indeed the perceptions of family that we differ on with respect to the Opposition and in respect of women in the work force—this is the very point of this answer. PARA.TAB: There is a great deal in the recent package announced by the Prime Minister for Australian women. This Government's performance on this issue does not rest on that single statement but on nine years of solid performance in this area. TALK.START.PARA: —They have to go to work to keep the family going.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the level of complaints from consumers about their dealings with insurance companies and superannuation agents? What action is the Government taking to determine whether consumers are getting adequate impartial advice and guidance from the agents they deal with? Is the issue of disclosure of commissions being examined?

—I understand that the Trade Practices Commission has instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against the Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society with regard to the sale of insurance policies to Aborigines in remote Queensland communities. The proceedings involve allegations of misleading, deceptive and unconscionable conduct by agents of CML. But because I think that matter may be before the court if not this week, then next week, I will not comment on that particular case.

PARA.TAB: As far as the general marketing practices of life insurance and superannuation agents are concerned, there are widespread misgivings and concerns in the Australian community about the practices, I think highlighted by some notorious cases. Unfortunately, that leads to a stereotyping and a sort of caricature of life insurance agents which is undeserved, no doubt, by the great majority of the 16,000 life insurance agencies or agents around Australia.

As I announced in Launceston a week or so ago to the Life Insurance Underwriters Association conference, there will be an inquiry undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission into the actual experience of Australians out in the marketplace purchasing these very important policies which are designed to deal with security in old age, with the possibility of loss of employment through disability or accident or some sort of illness, or what should happen in the case of death. It is a very important part of future planning for Australians. It is important to know whether some of the problems that arise are widespread and how they should be remedied. There seems to me to be confusion, for example, as to whether a life insurance agent is an impartial adviser or just a sales person. I think that this confusion of identity can lead to some unfortunate experiences for those who purchase these policies. What is the impact of early termination? We know that if these policies are terminated early, quite often there are no benefits available at all.

The question of disclosure of commissions is a very contentious matter, with arguments on all sides. Unless the purchaser of a policy knows that an agent is earning a commission and the scope of that commission, they might not be able to ascertain whether they are being offered a product simply because higher commission attaches, whereas the life insurance agents argue that there is another side to that debate. We need empirical experience gathered by the Trade Practices Commission, and it is on the basis of that unbiased survey of what happens in the marketplace that the Government can come to reasonable policy decisions.

I know that Senator West is particularly concerned about these matters as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation under the chairmanship of the junior senator from Tasmania, Senator Sherry. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: One Nation: Employment Needs of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, Senator Newman and Senator Spindler submitted letters in accordance with standing order 75, one proposing a matter of urgency and the other a matter of public importance. In accordance with the standing order, to decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate I determined the matter by ballot in the presence of Senator Newman and Senator Spindler and the Clerk of the Senate.As a result of that procedure, I now read Senator Newman's letter:

PARA.TAB: Dear Mr President
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move—
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Keating One Nation package to give any attention to the employment needs of Australian women.
Yours sincerely
Jocelyn Newman
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The failure of the Keating One Nation package to give any attention to the employment needs of Australian women.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the bitter taste that has been left in the mouths of Australian women as a result of the mini-Budget delivered the other night by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is an important issue which should be debated by the Senate. All around Australia, women are asking, `Is that all there is?'.

PARA.TAB: On Sunday we will be celebrating International Women's Day. We will be celebrating a day which recognises the long fight women have had to achieve equality in our society. We will be looking to see the point which women have reached—where they have arrived at. How many Australian women will be able to celebrate International Women's Day this Sunday? There will be women who are unemployed. Many of them, of course, are not entitled to unemployment benefit but they are part of families in which poverty is a very real problem. There will be women who work inadequate hours because the businesses for which they work are in difficulty and are struggling to keep their heads above water. There will be women in the welfare sector who are struggling with poverty. That is the bitter taste that is in women's mouths as they prepare for International Women's Day this Sunday.

It is almost unbelievable that the package Mr Keating flaunted so loudly has offered little or no hope for thousands of Australian women who are seeking employment, or training and education for future employment. Only last Friday in Sydney a delegate of the Australian Services Union turned to Senator West and said, `Why is there nothing for women, Senator West, in your Prime Minister's statement?'. That is not an unusual view amongst the women that I have spoken to since that package came out. Indeed, I draw the Senate's attention to the terms of the motion because they are virtually what Senator Sowada said this week in a press statement which she also released on this subject. I could not have agreed with her more.

Those who want paid work and who are fortunate enough to have a job in the paid work force have been offered no positive initiatives to ensure financial security through savings plans or tax cuts. They have not been given incentives to encourage and reward those of us who want to work more productively for themselves and for their employers and, eventually, for their country. Those incentives benefit everybody. They will help get this country out of recession. But this Government has failed to acknowledge the need for assistance in those areas for people in the work force. A blind eye has been turned to Australian workers with family responsibilities. There is no help in the Government's package for women who combine paid work with work in the home, caring for children, for sick or elderly relatives. In total, the One Nation package ignores the employment needs of women.

My colleagues Senator Knowles and Senator Macdonald will also take part in this debate and will talk about women in rural areas who are having difficulty with employment, younger women and small business women. In the short time I have available today I want to canvass education and skills, jobs, tax, the family responsibilities of workers, and superannuation and savings.

The basic employment need of women is their ability to access quality education and skills training. I am pleased to see one thing in the package the Prime Minister released, and that is that he has adopted our proposal for a substantial injection of funds into TAFE, which is of tremendous importance to women who are trying to re-enter the paid work force. It is the place where they start their way back. Under our Fightback education proposals we targeted TAFE to be an important area of training for women through our promise to transform and expand it into a high status, vocational education and training system.

Women today face an appalling problem in trying to get higher education. Up to 50,000 qualified school leavers have missed out on university places this year. More than 150,000 students have been locked out of TAFE. That plight has been made even more desperate by the recession we had to have, caused by the Prime Minister that we are stuck with. They cannot get a job while they wait to get into a training institution. The education and training of our young have to be among the most important investments any country can make. It is all very well to go on about giving girls equal opportunity and encouraging them to take up maths and sciences and then letting them fall off the edge of a cliff when they leave school. It is cruel and it is no way to raise the next generation. We have just seen an utter failure in the Government's ideologically driven policy for universities.

Unemployment has to be the highest concern of all Australians today. There have been no practical solutions for job creation in areas where women's employment needs to be encouraged. Senator Sowada said this week that unfortunately the only jobs which will be created for women by the economic statement appear to be as waitresses and chambermaids for the tourism industry. As a member of a family that is active in the tourism industry, I hope that it does grow and thrive and that there will be jobs there, but we are turning out youngsters who have a variety of aspirations. Should that be all that they can aspire to? Surely they want choice and diversity. P.P. McGuinness in the Australian this week said:

SPEECH.PARA: How will the Keating bonus for families and the road and rail works job creation affect the Government's election prospects for next year? Hardly at all, in that within a few months the bonus will be spent and forgotten while the jobs will be for the most part inferior to those the newborn navvies and fettlers held before the recession.

There will not be many jobs for women in that lot. Senator Sowada was also right when she claimed that there appears to be little assistance for the 353,000 women looking for full time or part time work or for the 103,000 women who have given up in disgust. Those are the women who will not be celebrating next Sunday, those hundreds of thousands of women who cannot get the work that they need. The Australian and the Victorian Councils of Social Service said:
The economic statement gave little hope and help to 900,000 unemployed Australians.

The Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Salvation Army and the Melbourne City Mission all voiced their concern that the statement would fail to generate jobs. Mr Challen, the Brotherhood's Executive Director, said he was disappointed that the Prime Minister had acknowledged that jobless levels would remain high next year. On top of this is the tragedy of youth unemployment, as I mentioned earlier, which has now got to the stage where one in three young Australians are unable to find work and earn an living. This gets worse as every day goes by.

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand the real picture of women's participation in the paid work force. The unemployment rate for women in January 1992 was 10.5 per cent. The number of unemployed women was then shown as 368,700. That figure is made up of 280,400 women looking for full time work and 88,300 women looking for part time work. There are 99,300 young unemployed women aged 15 to 19 years, 33,100 looking for part time work and 66,200 looking for full time work. These are not just statistics; they are our daughters, our neighbours and our young friends starting out in life. How cruel can a country be to do that to the young?

On top of the 959,700 who are actually unemployed, an ABS survey in January showed that a further three-quarters of a million Australians wanted to work and were ready to work in four weeks time but were not actually looking for work. Many of them were discouraged about doing so. Of those, over half a million were women. Another ABS survey for January shows that over half a million Australians were underemployed in January this year. This number was made up of 94,400 full time workers who due to the recession had been put back in the number of hours they could work and 450,900 people who were working part time but wanted to increase their hours.

Our Fightback program is directed at removing the financial pressures that are disadvantaging business across the nation, forcing them under with a burden of unfair and unrewarding tax costs. This noose around the businessman's and businesswoman's neck is tightening. As it strangles our business investment, so it destroys any prospect of offering jobs to our growing army of young Australians, who face the prospect of years of unemployment.

Unless we reach out and grab the opportunity that is being offered to us through Fightback!, we will slip further and further behind. Until we adopt the economic and financial proposals of Fightback! we can never expect, nor hope, to build any foundations to expand our economy and create sustainable real job growth. That is where Fightback! succeeds and One Nation fails. Our package is a far-seeing reform package for the decade. The mini-Budget, although packaged as a four-year plan, is really just a stopgap measure to deal with the urgency of the moment.

Of the policies that will help women, we in the Opposition will offer the unemployed earlier access to programs which combine employment and training; we will increase the funds for voluntary organisations, with an increased emphasis on training; we will provide a limited voluntary community based work for benefits scheme; and we will work with the States to ensure that at risk young people are given all the help they need to make the right decisions and are pointed in the right direction to help them as soon as they make the transition from school to further training and then into employment.

The Keating Government, as we know, returns no bracket creep at all to the 50 per cent of taxpayers earning under $21,000 a year. Further, One Nation also discriminates against women, youth and the elderly in that no tax relief is offered to these people in the group who are low income earners. Nearly two million people earning less than $20,700 are women, nearly one million young people aged under 25 years are earning less than $21,000, and nearly half a million are people aged 65 and over. All those groups have income of less than $20,700 and the Government will give them not a penny of tax relief, not even lifting the tax threshold for them.

The coalition's Fightback proposal will raise the tax free threshold from $5,400 to $7,000. That will mean that another 320,000 people will no longer pay any income tax at all. Women—there are nearly a couple of million of them—earning between $7,000 and $20,700 will have their taxation rate reduced to 16.2 per cent.

Under the Federal Government we know only too well that the overall burden of personal tax is and has been excessive and those tax rates significantly reduce the incentives to work. Many on low to middle incomes can more than double their incomes without paying a higher rate of tax under Fightback. There is an encouragement to work more and earn more and keep it. People are sick and tired of the Government having its hands in their back pockets taking their money before they have even had a chance to look at it.

About 95 per cent of taxpayers will face a tax rate no higher than 30c in the dollar under our reforms, compared with the 38c and 46c currently paid under this Government.The tax benefits have to be seen in the wider context of the package. Most importantly, low and middle income people will benefit from the increased job opportunities which will flow from the labour market and structural reforms. That means jobs and jobs mean independence and that means no welfare dependence.

It is interesting to see that the Institute of Public Affairs has pointed out that just over 86 per cent of all pay as you earn tax collected goes to the Government's social welfare payments. It is no wonder that families, particularly, in Australia are feeling heavily burdened by the pressure from taxation. Fightback will remove almost $20 billion—not million, but billion—in taxes on inputs, employment and exports so that we can bolster the competitive position of our industries. That is how jobs will be created for Australians—the old, young and middle-aged; men and women.

Fightback will benefit those women who want paid work by the creation of an extra two million real jobs—not `make work' jobs—by the end of the decade. We will not only provide jobs; women who work in the paid work force desperately need help with inflexible working arrangements and family responsibilities and our package recognises that. We recognise that our industrial relations policy will enable women to negotiate for packages which suit them personally and give them better opportunities for care for the elderly as well as child-care. They will be able to get the advantage of the extra $90m which we are putting into the child-care system to enable increased family support. It is very important for families to feel that the Government understands their needs in this area and that they can work with their employers to get the best deal possible for them to combine their responsibilities in the workplace and at home.

The coalition also recognises that families need special financial help and so we will double the family allowance for families whose combined incomes are below $30,000. We will increase the family allowance by 50 per cent for those families with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000. We will increase the annual dependant spouse rebate. We will increase the sole parent pension by 8 per cent and the sole parent rebate by 4.8 per cent. We will increase the family allowance supplement by 6 per cent and help sole parents re-enter the work force with an increase in the transition to work allowance from $100 to $400.

What will One Nation do—this mini-Budget that Mr Keating brought down? What is he going to do for families? He is going to give a one-off cash bribe on 2 April. That is an approach which Father Peter Norden, a spokesman for the Catholic Social Services in Victoria, described as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: a Tattslotto approach of cash grants to families in need was a poor response to the more permanent problem of inadequate dole payments and lack of jobs.

The Government's package offers nothing to working parents. Not a word is to be found in the Prime Minister's speech about child-care, nor in the statement itself. The Government has totally failed to recognise the need for women to have a retirement income. There is no recognition of the fact that women go in and out of the work force; they have broken work patterns through child rearing, divorce or widowhood.

PARA.TAB: The Fightback package is really very revolutionary in encouraging women and their spouses, where it is appropriate, to contribute to retirement saving schemes for which either the wife or her spouse can claim a tax rebate. That encourages them to put money away during the time they are in the home until the time when they can return to the work force. These days most women do aspire to return to the work force when their children are older. But the women return when they are older and when there is less time to assemble sufficient retirement income funds.

The coalition's Fightback package recognises that women can start doing that while they are out of the work force and can continue it when they go back into the work force. Women who are over 45 and who have perhaps come back in after widowhood or divorce can put in a lump sum in one year and get a substantial tax rebate to enable them to boost the size of their eventual retirement savings.

These are important and practical ways to help women in the work force prepare for their retirement. Seventy per cent of old age pensioners today are women. Too many women are condemned to poverty in their old age. We are determined to try to make life easier for women in those circumstances.

We are also helping young Australians by giving them access to 75 per cent of their accumulated superannuation savings in order to qualify for their first home loan. They will be able to get a $2,000 one-off payment from the Federal Government if they are in families earning less than $40,000.

It is very important that these women be encouraged to save in whatever form they choose to save. So many women these days are worried about the big companies. They are worried about the failure of financial institutions. They are worried about funds that they cannot see and they cannot control. They do not think that the Government's 3 per cent compulsory employer contribution scheme is satisfactory because so many of them are either not covered by it or they are in casual employment, which means that the overheads and administration costs eat up their superannuation. That scheme does not work. Retirement savings accounts will be a very valuable way of retirement saving for those women.

Women will be given the opportunity to get jobs, to get skills, to go in and out of the work force as they feel the need, consistent with their family responsibilities. They will get help with their child-care. They will get help to provide for their own retirement income by way of tax-free savings schemes of one kind or another.

It is very important that throughout their working life women are given these opportunities to retain financial independence. For too long they have been treated as somebody's dependant. Of course, that is not so any more, but while they remain on unemployment lists they are the nation's dependants. They may not be the dependant of a man but they are just as much a dependant, and their self-esteem is affected just as badly as by having to put their hand out for the housekeeping or for every penny they have to spend.

If they have to put their hand out to government, it is just as bad for their morale. Women too want the independence that comes from having money in their pocket, the earning of which they have contributed to.

Mr Keating's plan certainly did not grab most people in Australia. It was interesting to see that P.P. McGuinness was particularly concerned about women. He said that the most curious thing about Paul Keating's mini-Budget was how old-fashioned, male-orientated and naive it was. In the Financial Review—Government senators were trying to drown out comments relating to it today in Question Time—Sue Neales did not give the nod to the Federal Government's plan to lead us out of the economic wilderness in this recession because, as she said:

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to specific policies as enunciated in Labor's One Nation statement of last week and the Liberal's Fightback package, Dr Hewson's approach seems light years ahead of the new Prime Minister's.
I remind honourable senators also of the ASU delegate who said, `There's nothing in it for women'.

PARA.TAB: The Government has failed those women. Mr Keating and his party members might prefer their women to be barefoot, pregnant and in the kitchen but Australian women are facing the grim realities of a ghastly recession and what they need are jobs, jobs, jobs.
