TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs, jobs, jobs are just what I am going to be talking about this afternoon. Senator Newman trots out every year at this time her statement for International Women's Day. We have been hearing it for several years now. It is the only time that she seems to bother to focus on this aspect of her shadow portfolio.

PARA.TAB: In her introduction she talked about this concept of a `bitter taste'. I presume that that `bitter taste' has something to do with the consumption tax that would be introduced if the coalition were to be elected.

If Senator Newman were aware of the way in which this Government has targeted women and implemented a whole range of policies for them, she would not have made the kinds of comments she has made today. I suggest that she watch out for the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on International Women's Day. She will probably be rather embarrassed to have made a number of the statements she has made today. Senator Newman talked about women struggling with poverty; yet she failed to acknowledge the struggle that women would have if the coalition were ever to get the opportunity to introduce its Fightback package. I have here in front of me just some of the rhetoric used by Senator Newman—rhetoric that has been absolutely discredited by exposure of the detail of the cutbacks in public expenditure proposed by the coalition in the Fightback package.

It is all very well for Senator Newman to say, `There should be more money for this' and `We should spend more money on that'. Senator Newman's Party is committed to cutting back public expenditure. The Opposition has a Thatcherite policy—a New Zealand-type regressive model. The Opposition's consumption tax, combined with the dramatic cutbacks in the public sector, would be devastating for all Australians but they would particularly impact on women.

Let me talk just a little about the One Nation package, because Senator Newman seems to think that all these initiatives are failures. A four-year strategy for growth does not sound like a failure to me. Is increased expenditure on labour market programs a failure? Are reforms for small business failures? Is $720m on vocational training a failure? What about the national focus on tourism expansion? Senator Newman would count that as a failure too. She would dismiss the very real role that women play in the tourism industry. They object to being dismissed as chambermaids and whatever other terms Senator Newman uses to refer to them. That is an insult to the very important role that Australian women play in the tourism industry. What about the increased expenditure on the textiles, clothing and footwear industry? As far as Senator Newman is concerned, all of that is a mere nothing; that is just a failure.
I come now to the detail, to some of the statistics that Senator Newman seems to be unaware of. I suggest that Senator Newman should read yesterday's Australian, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Female workers look set to emerge from the recession . . . Not only have they been sheltered from most of the job cuts but they also enjoyed higher pay rises than males as the economy began contracting in 1990.

PARA.TAB: Detailed figures released yesterday by the Bureau of Statistics show that although males fared slightly better on base pay rates, females claimed a higher rise on total earnings through greater overtime and over-award payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the issues concerning women in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. What has to be remembered is that the Prime Minister is making this statement against a background of nine years—yes, nine years—of major commitment to women's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —900,000 unemployed.

—Senator Macdonald would not have a clue about women's policy, because he does not keep up with the kinds of changes that have been implemented over that nine-year period. The Prime Minister's statement is a four-year strategy for growth. It recognises that the best way to look after everybody in society—and I mean everybody—is to give them jobs, and that includes women. It is not so very long ago that Senator Newman came into this place suggesting that women should not be in the work force; that the only reason they were in the work force was that they did not have enough money to live on a single wage. She did not agree with women being in the work force. She has obviously caught up with the reality that Australian women want to be part of the work force in many cases.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at this Government's record on jobs and social infrastructure—a social infrastructure that would be completely undercut and in fact devastated by this Fightback package, which would slash public sector expenditure. When this Government came to office, 44 per cent of women were in the work force; that figure is now over 52 per cent. This high participation rate has happened partly because the Government has created jobs and partly because we have made it possible for women to go to work by creating over 100,000 child-care places to add to the 46,000 that were there when we started. That is what I mean about social infrastructure.

One of the great achievements of this Government is that women are finally being accepted as an integral part of the Australian work force. They are playing their part and they are being accepted and given recognition for the part that they play. They are not just some emergency work force to be brought in as the need arises. They have a legitimate place and they have legitimate skills and expertise.

Working women have already benefited from this Government's introduction of traineeships in areas where women's skills have previously not been recognised. They are already taking 52 per cent of the places in higher education compared with 46 per cent in 1983. Increased expenditure on labour market programs will ensure that those who are unfortunate enough to be unemployed long term will not lose their skills or their confidence in the process.

This Government's retirement incomes policy has extended superannuation for the first time to many women workers, most of whom were excluded in the past. We have amended the Sex Discrimination Act and extended award superannuation and we are now legislating for the superannuation guarantee levy.

Women, especially those of a non-English speaking background, will also benefit disproportionately from the extra funds for literacy programs. In recent years, women have been increasingly represented and very successful in small business. So they will be able to have further successes through the self-employment assistance program, the changes to capital gains tax and the tax treatment of non-performing loans by banks and the extra funding support for small firms entering export markets. I am sure that small business women would say that none of those items were failures to the extent that women will be affected.

So much for saying that this package does not meet the needs of women. There is a lot in it for women. The Government's performance over nine years includes many initiatives that I will now detail. For instance, in employment, it was this Government that passed the Sex Discrimination Act, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act. We introduced permanent part time work for Australian Public Service employees, we ratified ILO Convention No. 156 on workers with family responsibilities, and we established the work and family unit and the equal pay unit in the Department of Industrial Relations. This Government also launched the Australian women's employment strategy.

With regard to education and training, we were the ones to introduce schemes to improve work opportunities for female apprentices. Under previous Liberal governments, female apprentices were not recognised unless they were working in very traditional areas. This Government introduced the Australian traineeship schemes and the national policy for the education of girls in Australian schools, and announced a national plan of action for women in TAFE and the national plan of action for women in tertiary education. It is only under this Government that women have begun to outnumber men in higher education for the first time.

Let us now look at women's employment. Women's employment has been less affected by the recession than men's employment. The current seasonally adjusted unemployment rates for males and females as of January 1992 are 10.6 per cent and 9.8 per cent respectively. Between May and November 1991, women's labour force participation declined slightly by only 0.3 per cent to 51.5 per cent, after reaching a peak of 52.3 per cent in September 1991. Nevertheless, this Government recognises that women make up a large percentage of the disadvantaged. The following programs are directed at enhancing their employment prospects. The Commonwealth Employment Service, CES, has established equity targets for the placement of disadvantaged groups, including sole parents, the majority of whom are women.

Additional assistance for unemployed people has been provided in Skillshare as part of the March 1991 industry statement, which increases benefits for women. The jobs, education and training program has also been a very important part of the programs we have specifically initiated for women.

I have spent half of my time focusing on the very proud record of first the Hawke Government and now the Keating Government in relation to women in Australia. Now I would like to focus on just what would happen if the coalition were actually to come to office and how that would impact on women workers. Women workers would be among the worst affected victims of the Hewson consumption tax package. Earlier Senator Newman was talking about government having its hands in the pockets of workers. But that is nothing compared to what it would be like if the coalition were to have its hands in the pockets and the purses and the wallets of people at the supermarkets, at the child-care centre, paying the electricity bill, et cetera. Wherever we went to spend our dollars we would have to pay that 15 per cent.

As I had the opportunity to visit Canada recently I have some small experience of how that policy is working there. In Canada the consumption tax is only 7 per cent federally because it is also applied at the State level, which still only brings it up to 13 per cent. What is happening in Canada? The Federal Government there is actually looking at reducing the 7 per cent consumption tax because there has been such a reaction. In fact, people are going over the border to do their shopping in the United States because they cannot cope with the impact of a consumption tax of 7 per cent, or 7 per cent plus 6 per cent in some States, which is 13 per cent. Here in Australia the coalition is still wedded to this idea that a 15 per cent consumption tax is somehow just.

We should look at some of the programs that were introduced under the Labor Government during the 1980s. These programs included the Affirmative Action Agency and two special programs in the Department of Industrial Relations. Under the Opposition's Fightback package, the Affirmative Action Agency would be abolished, along with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commission is not being abolished. The Affirmative Action Agency is being put into the Department and the Human Rights Commission is not being abolished.

—Senator Newman must have been able to twist a few arms in recent months because a number of her colleagues have spoken over the years about the abolition of both those agencies. The agency's policies and reports to Parliament on the equal employment performances of all workplaces in the private sector with more than 100 employees have brought very important results. It plays an important role in advising business on how to implement best practices. It received over 2,500 inquiries from business in the past year alone.

PARA.TAB: In John Hewson's consumption tax package he proposes that the agency should be abolished but without any impact on the legislative guarantees of equal employment opportunity. Somehow it is going to be absorbed into the Department, which will already be overloaded. There will be severe cutbacks, because the whole philosophy of the Opposition is to have cutbacks in the public sector. Yet somehow the Affirmative Action Agency, which is there doing a good job now, is supposed to do the same job over in the Department, which will be under-resourced. It simply does not make sense. Exactly the same thing applies in relation to the coalition's cost-cutting proposals for the Department of Industrial Relations. That would have the effect of abolishing the equal pay and work and family units of that Department. The equal pay unit carries out or commissions research on pay equity issues—issues that, if Senator Newman is really interested in improvements for Australian women in relation to their place in the labour market, one would think she would want to protect.

One politically significant effect of the Hewson proposal would be that there would be no expert departmental advice or recommendations on the significant damage to women's earnings if the coalition's enterprise bargaining policy were ever put into practice. The Hewson cuts would also eliminate the work and family unit. This program was set up to develop, oversee and help the Government report to the UN International Labour Organisation on how it is implementing ILO convention 156.

I note that just this week, when Minister Fatin announced a major public education program to try to get parents to take equal responsibility in relation to the tasks involved in caring for a family, Senator Newman rubbished that program because she does not see it as important. Yet it is fundamental to women's place in the Australian work force. Women cannot continue to do the double shift, working at home and working in the work force. Yet Senator Newman dismisses this very important educative program, which is all about changing attitudes, all about getting both parents to accept their responsibilities for the family.

Let me conclude by referring to a report in the Australian soon after the coalition's Fightback policy was announced. On 25 November, under the headline `Package fails to woo women', Nick Richardson wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal Coalition's taxation package has so far failed to win over the majority of women, who believe their families will suffer under the policy.
Polls published yesterday show 42 per cent of women think their families will be worse off and 17 per cent do not know what impact the policy will have on their families.

I can assure Senator Newman and Senator Macdonald that in the coming months those women, who are not sure what the impact will be, will certainly know a great deal more about the impact because that is going to be the focus of many debates such as this. We will be looking to the overseas experience in regard to the consumption tax. We will be looking at the $10 billion cuts the Opposition proposes for the public sector. We will be looking at things such as the cessation of the sole parent pension when the youngest child turns 12, which would enable the Opposition to make savings of $115m. What about the restriction of pension eligibility to wives of disability support pensioners? In that regard the Opposition would make savings of $199.3m. The uniform age pension, regardless of women's different experience, will make savings of $118m; and the enforcement of the age pension residency provisions another $60m.

PARA.TAB: Wherever we look in the Fightback package, the coalition wants to save money. It wants to cut this and cut that, and it is absolutely uncommitted to women. It is uncommitted to those very strong reforms that were made first under the Hawke Government and will be continued under the Keating Government. I suggest that Senator Newman and members of the Opposition closely watch the Prime Minister's statement on International Women's Day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice and on behalf of Senator Coulter, I move that the motion be amended by adding at the end the following words: `and for the package's failure to address the segregation of women in the work force with the result that Australia remains the most sex segregated work force in the OECD'.

—Senator Sowada, it is necessary for you to do that in two stages; that is, following the contingent notice of motion moved by the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Coulter, you would move for the suspension of standing orders and then you would be able to move a precise amendment. Is it your intention to move for the suspension of standing orders?
—I was advised otherwise on how to pursue this procedure.
—The question is that the motion that Standing Orders be suspended according to the contingent notice of motion of Senator Coulter be agreed to.
—We are not opposing the moving of a motion. There was only doubt as to the procedure under which it was moved.
—In the light of Senator Newman's comment, I put the question again.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sowada, I suggest you move the amendment.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:
"and the package's failure to address the segregation of women in the work force, with the result that Australia remains the most sex segregated work force in the OECD.".

TALK.START.PARA: —That amendment will be put before we put the urgency motion itself at the end of the debate. So I ask you to speak to both the amendment and the urgency motion.
—In response to my question on Monday about jobs for women in the economic statement, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the statement talks about people, not men or women. There is nothing specified in relation to men or women in the statement.

This is perfectly true and it is precisely this aspect of the statement about which we are critical. It appears that the statement has forgotten the fact that Australia has one of the most highly sex segregated work forces in the world and, despite the claims of 800,000 jobs in four years, we really question whether this will go towards meeting the tremendous needs plainly evident in the female work force. This is why the Australian Democrats will be supporting this motion moved by the Opposition today, in conjunction with an amendment to highlight the failure of the Government's policies in helping to break down gender barriers in the work force and improve the participation of women in non-traditional areas.

PARA.TAB: In the week of International Women's Day 1992, it is an astonishing fact that Australia has one of the most sex segregated work forces of all its OECD counterparts. Nearly a decade since the Federal sex discrimination Acts were codified the situation for women in the work force has little improved. We are facing the lack of success of many of the Government's affirmative action policies as women remain clustered in traditional professions which are mainly low skilled, low paid and low value areas.

For example, 76 per cent of all clerical positions are held by women; 64 per cent of all jobs in retail sales are held by women; and women are still clustered in teaching, nursing, community services and certain sections of manufacturing. On the other hand, less than 12 per cent of all full time managerial positions are held by women. When I read the One Nation document it was with a growing sense of despair that I saw that once again the Government had failed to address the severe problem of female unemployment in Australia.

Male unemployment is well catered for. The Government is to spend millions on massive infrastructure projects—railways, roads, wharves and airports—and to that the Democrats have no objection. However, it must be clear to even the most disinterested person that the building industry is not a major employer of women but it does employ men from unskilled labour to the architect. This is not to say, however, that women are incapable of holding jobs in these fields. Albeit slowly, more and more women are moving into these areas. My colleague Senator Bourne, for example, is an architect by training and I am no stranger to heavy work and dirty hands in the archaeological field.

So how large is the problem? The number of discouraged job seekers as at September 1991 increased by a whopping 37 per cent to 138,200 and 75 per cent of these were women. The ABS has another category, not in the labour force, comprising people who may like to work but who are not actually looking for work or immediately available to start. As at September last year these people numbered over 3,643,000 and some 68 per cent of these were women. Of the 819,300 people who indicated a preference for part time work, 73 per cent were women and 41 per cent of these said family reasons were preventing them from actively seeking work; 77 per cent of these people said their reasons were child-care related.

Repeatedly, areas such as child-care and maternity leave are identified as the biggest impediments to women's participation in the work force, yet they are so easily remedied and not addressed in the economic statement. There is little point to women entering traditional areas of male work if they are going to be sacked if they become pregnant, denied maternity leave, discouraged from applying for entitlements, unable to find child-care places or find that the cost of child-care is prohibitive. I remind the Government that the Labour Council in New South Wales—the paradigm of labour market relations in New South Wales—actually sacked two women who were on approved maternity leave. Senator West holds her head in shame, and so she should. It must have been the worst example of labour relations in New South Wales; not to mention the five other workers who also got the sack. So much for consultation.

Where benefits exist women should be encouraged to apply and to exercise their rights to child-care. Why is it that fewer than half the women in Victoria who are entitled to maternity leave take it even though it has been built into awards for more than 10 years? Many of these women are unaware of their rights. However, many unions fail to alert women to these rights, and female membership rates in unions are low and the senior ranks are still male dominated. Industries are quick to whine about any attempts to improve working conditions for women. A survey conducted by Price Waterhouse shows fewer than half of the industries are interested in affirmative action programs and around 15 per cent are willing to offer child-care facilities. The same survey showed that 30 per cent of men actually resented affirmative action initiatives.

Women still only earn 80 per cent of male average weekly earnings, and 81.7 per cent of earning males work full time and a full year compared with 46.4 per cent of women. This is because the major proportion of women have another almost full time job—wife, mother and partner. This restricts their ability to conform to the male idea of job structure. The male idea of a career path is full time work, full year work, mobility to follow career opportunities and no outside work responsibilities. None of this applies to most women and this inability to slot into the expected role discriminates against them. The above figures proves this. A valuable resource is being wasted and the Government is blinded by the big picture.

So what measures are being taken by the Government to address the problem of female unemployment? Where are the jobs for women in the economic statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? Given the sex segregated nature of the work force where are the jobs for women in road and rail construction, infrastructure support and public works?

Let us turn to a large employer of women, the textile, clothing and footwear industry. In that industry 65 per cent of the employees are women, and yet this sector of the economy has suffered massive job losses over the last 18 months. Some 30,000 jobs have been lost in the TCF industry as a result of restructuring forced on the industry by this Government, which seems bent on making sure Australia competes on a level playing field even when hardly anyone overseas is doing the same thing. These jobs will not suddenly re-emerge when the recession is over. They are permanently lost and there is no guarantee that the slack will be taken up by the 200,000 jobs to be created in the tourism industry.

The Australian Democrats fully support the TCF union in its call for a freeze on quota levels and out of quota duty rates in 1992, and a review of the tariff phase-down. The economic statement promises an augmented TCF industry development strategy to help existing firms restructure, but no change to its relentless policy of tariff reduction which has severely damaged Australia's manufacturing base. There is no real help or jobs in the statement for women who are employed in the TCF industry. As it stands, many women will have to wait for the expected private sector recovery, which will hopefully create jobs in sales, clerical and manufacturing sectors.

However, as I said earlier, the absence in the economic statement of jobs for women can be partly traced back to structural inequalities in the workplace and the sex segregated nature of the work force. The ABS claims that the over $7,000 difference in earnings for full-time males and females was partly related to differences in educational and occupational characteristics. Clearly, more educational opportunities for women and girls in non-traditional fields will in the long term enable women to benefit from work creation programs in public infrastructure projects, engineering and related fields.

Education is seen as a key factor in achieving equality between men and women. A 1985 Schools Commission report during International Women's Year concluded that, overall, females were educationally disadvantaged and sexism was pervasive in our school system. Equal opportunity legislation designed to improve educational opportunities for women, hence employment prospects for women, has not succeeded in achieving equal participation on a secondary level or specifically at a tertiary level.

The imbalance in women's participation is determined by a number of factors. These include choice of matriculation subjects, masculinist curricula, a lack of mentors, a lack of self-confidence, parenting responsibilities and financial problems. These are all important factors underlying the participation of women in higher education and mirror the obstacles in the work force.

Women's participation in the higher education sector is gradually improving, despite financial disincentives, which include fees in the form of HECS, and inadequate student financial assistance. Once in education institutions, women encounter problems such as a lack of child-care facilities, inadequate safety and security provisions and gender exclusive curriculum. Women now comprise 53 per cent of undergraduate enrolments, yet their participation begins to diminish at a postgraduate level.

Of those women enrolled in undergraduate degrees, at least 50 per cent are concentrated in traditional areas such as nursing, arts and education. This clustering is specific to women, whereas men are more evenly spread among all faculties. This sets a pattern for women in the work force and their subsequent concentration in lower paid, lower skilled and lower valued areas. In non-traditional areas such as engineering, in many institutions women represent less than 10 per cent of enrolments on all degree levels and average 10.1 per cent in Australia as a whole.

In the past decade women have increased their participation at the honours degree level. However, there is still significant attrition of female students beyond the honours year in most disciplines. The number of female postgraduates studying for higher degrees and PhDs is less than half of that of male postgraduates. One influence of women's participation in education is the limited role models in academia with less than 10 per cent of senior academic positions and professorships held by women. Women tend to be untenured, part-time, and working as tutor staff, junior assistants and sub-lecturers. On average only 20 per cent of research and teaching positions are held by women.

Successful participation in university education is a necessary step towards entry into a wide range of professional careers, including academic research and teaching. Until education opportunities for women are expanded, women's access to the work force is somewhat limited. What incentives are there for women to enter higher education with the paucity of student financial assistance available?

Women with children are specifically disadvantaged when the maximum Austudy rate available to them is $165.20 per week. That represents a measly $8,638 for them and their dependants to survive on per year. The imbalance between earned income for women and men is also reflected in student incomes. A recent study into student finances demonstrates that women receive $36 less per week than their male counterparts in the higher education system.

Over the decade the gender imbalance in higher education has remained resistant to legislative action. Any attempts to introduce financial barriers to participation in education will hit hard at traditionally disadvantaged groups such as women. Certainly, this will not be helped by the Opposition's policy of introducing vouchers and what effectively will be fees for higher education. I believe that this will lead significantly to a return to the pre-Whitlam days when families could only afford to educate one member of their family, which usually was the eldest son.

The One Nation economic statement and the GST provide no new opportunities for women's increased participation in the higher education system and fail to outline positive measures in the provision of on-campus child-care or boosts to students assistance that would remove some of the obstacles that prevent women's participation.

The only jobs that appear to be created for women in the One Nation package are those in the tourism industry. We certainly do not have any argument with job creation in that sector. However, I would point to an inconsistency in the Government's package. The Government is suggesting that 800,000 jobs will be created over four years. Yet if one turns to page 88 of the One Nation document, one sees:

SPEECH.PARA: In the next eight years international tourism to Australia is forecast to more than double and 200,000 new jobs could be generated.
I would like the Government to explain—and this is a genuine question—whether the 200,000 jobs that will be created are included

in the 800,000 jobs which are to be created over the next four years. What relationship do the 200,000 jobs in the tourism industry to be created over the next decade bear to the 800,000 jobs which are mentioned elsewhere in the statement to be created over the next four years? That is a very genuine question that we would ask in view of the tourism projections contained in the package.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, quite clearly the Government has placed a great deal of faith in the marketplace to create jobs for women in those industries where they are traditionally segregated. PARA.TAB: This Labor Government is failing them miserably. Given the record of both the Hawke Government and the Keating Government, which sought to deregulate finance while leaving business to cope with a regulated wage structure, we should not be surprised at all.

This has been a major cause of the recession, or depression, and particularly of youth unemployment. The Liberal and National parties will institute training programs in direct partnership with the private sector through local employment boards. This Government, having been in government for nine long years, has locked 150,000 people out of TAFE. No. There is not one mention of this in the silly One Nation, `One Job', package. It is a shame that Mr Keating did not consider the plight of women—the young women, the women underemployed in their occupations—instead of his own job and his own residency at the Lodge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then they'll sack them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are with two documents to compare and contrast. I must say that it would be much more enjoyable if we had several hours in which to do it instead of a few minutes. I emphasise at the outset that the mistake that is continually made by the coalition is to believe that workers of whatever gender can somehow be differentiated from the general population. Fightback! makes every effort to make it look as if unions and their members are the enemies of the Australian people, somehow exclusive of the average mortgage or rent paying household, battling to keep up the payments and feed the family and certainly not female. Women workers are also consumers.

—Just listen to this; I think you might learn something. Women workers are also consumers, parents, trainees, students, and mortgage, rent and rate payers. PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Reynolds has summarised very effectively many of the measures that have been taken in the last nine years, and which will continue under this Government, to produce a state of affairs in Australia where women are in a far better position to deal with the many vicissitudes of a working women's life with its different phases.

The job increases over the last eight years have included nearly one million women. Traineeships have had a high proportion of success amongst women. Higher education now sees 52 per cent of women students. Superannuation, which I understand Senator Newman managed to skirt around without saying anything particularly useful, is for the first time available for many women. Extension of award superannuation has occurred over the last few years. Amendment of the Sex Discrimination Act has removed exemptions which affected women. We are now legislating for a superannuation guaranteed levy. These are many very solid and concrete examples of our concern for women. We will continue to be concerned.

I would like to address a number of the misapprehensions of some of the previous speakers, specifically Senator Knowles' reference to what she said was our total inability to achieve any sort of work force change. The Opposition seems once again to have completely ignored the impressive list of workplace agreements within the managed consensual system which this Government and our unions have built together. This the honourable senator managed to completely gloss over, to utterly ignore. These agreements include places where large numbers of women are employed, such as the Commonwealth Bank, Ansett Airlines, Johnson and Johnson, ACI Fibreglass, BHP, Hoover, Australian Airlines, Brambles, Alcan, Kelloggs, Bridgestone, Pacific Dunlop and Rheem, just to mention a few. So much for the accusation that there has been no restructuring in the work force, no capacity for workers to negotiate their own conditions, endorsed and monitored by an effective and an efficient industrial relations system which the Opposition, like the New Zealanders, would like to completely demolish.

I would like briefly to address Senator Sowada's amendment regarding the package's alleged failure to address the segregation of women in the work force with the result that Australia remains the most segregated work force in the OECD. We have known that for quite a long time. That sex segregation has been gradually diminishing over the years because of the measures that have been taken since 1983 by the Hawke Government and now by the Keating Government to try to redress the situation. It is not so long ago that when the Australian Statistician took out common award wages he looked at 2,500 common awards for males and 500 common awards for females, to give you some idea of the quite drastic segregation that previously applied within the Australian work force. We should also look at other ways in which we line up with the OECD and recognise that we have moved closer to genuine equal wages for women than any other OECD country. We are doing considerably better for a number of reasons, most of which go to the consensual nature of the Australian industrial relations system.

I would like to concentrate for a moment or two on what a Keating-led Labor Government will not do, issues which are either explicit or implicit in the coalition's Fightback package. One of the things we will not do is follow the confrontationist, worker hostile, union bashing, harsh and punitive formula of the coalition's Fightback, or some call it dieback, strategies. We will not be abolishing or diminishing the structures that protect the rights of women and women unionists. We will not be diminishing or removing structures such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. In fact, we are planning to expand it to cover other issues. We will not be diminishing or abolishing the Affirmative Action Agency. Despite Senator Newman's protestations, I refer honourable senators to chapter 16, page 268 of the Fightback! document, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further savings will be achieved by reducing the running costs of Comcare by 15 per cent and abolishing the Affirmative Action Agency.

These are the very words in Senator Newman's own document. We will not be following the New Zealand road to anarchy by stripping the Industrial Arbitration Commission of most of its functions and leaving the workers to try to survive the most blatant version of industrial Darwinism this country would ever have seen. We will not deny women workers the support and protection of unions. I draw attention to the fact that women are joining unions in greater proportions than they have done for some years. We will not deny unions the right to negotiate on behalf of the workers. We will not abolish junior rates. We will not be giving employers the right to discard workers—amongst whom women are the most vulnerable, especially if they happen to be young or Aboriginal or from a non-English speaking background—who refuse to accept wage cuts, no penalty rates and generally inferior conditions.

PARA.TAB: We certainly do not intend to carry out a slash and burn job to social security payments, as the New Zealand Government—which the Opposition admires so much—has done. Further, we certainly do not intend to coerce women and other vulnerable workers into accepting inferior working conditions by imposing lengthy qualifying conditions and other harsh conditions such as have been introduced in New Zealand which the Opposition, understandably, identifies as very close to its own ideology. Most of all, we shall certainly not be encumbering Australian women workers, consumers and parents with a 15 per cent tax on practically every purchase and transaction which would increase the cost of clothing, food, electricity and health charges and make losers of something like 60 to 70 per cent of households in Australia.

One of the most important changes over the last few years, and certainly one of our continuing measures to make life for working women and families with children a great deal more palatable—the single greatest liberating factor which, incidentally, provides a considerable amount of employment; it is very labour intensive—is children's services. I would like to emphasise that access and affordability, which are our principles, are likely to go out the window under the principles, such as they are, in the Fightback package.

Our own standards are illustrated by the fact that since 1983 the number of places in children's services has increased from 46,000 to 177,000 which, at December 1991, accommodated 284,000 children. This is an enormous increase on what was left for the women and families of Australia in 1983. Funding has risen four-fold to $370m in 1991-92 and the expansion program continues. Fee relief eligibility has expanded from 49,000 families to 130,000 families in 1992, partly as a result of being extended to users of approved commercial centres. This is a great leap forward in providing horizontal equity for those people who were unable to get access to the community centres which, at that point, were the only ones receiving subsidies.

The Fightback proposition would increase by 14 per cent the gap between what people are currently paying and what they would be required to pay for children's services under a coalition government. I have reduced that figure from 15 to 14 per cent to allow for the fact that wholesale sales tax is to be removed. As I have said before, wholesale sales tax is not a very substantial proportion of the costs of child-care, which is very heavily labour intensive. A 14 per cent increase would be the equivalent of about $17 a week on the cost of caring for each child. One can just imagine how that would be used as an excuse for failing to expand the number of child-care centres, diminishing access and affordability—which are things that we have stuck to religiously over the years—and possibly reducing standards.

There are very many issues that could be covered in talking about the enhancement of the status of women in Australia over the last eight or nine years. As I commented only two or three days ago, the measures taken in this country are seen as a model by many parts of the world. They are emulated, praised and admired. Over the years we have ensured that our policies and our platforms have developed, that the programs have been enhanced in order to improve accessibility; improve affordability for services; and expand the opportunities for women to train, to be included in the work force and to enhance their qualifications. Contrary to what has been accused, our One Nation statement includes a wide range of measures which will greatly improve the opportunity of women to either lift—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why haven't you talked about it?

—Because Senator Reynolds covered them all and I did not want honourable senators to be bored by being told the same thing over again. PARA.TAB: The greatest beneficiaries of our employment program since 1983 have been women. Women will benefit from the increase in family allowance supplement. Enormous things are being done for women. I am sure that Senator Reynolds will be so embarrassed when she realises that women unemployed now total 10.1 per cent of the work force, in spite of the fact that back in 1989 she was criticising people for an unemployment rate of 6.6 per cent.

What needs to be done to give women jobs in rural and remote Australia, or anywhere, is what needs to be done to give everyone jobs; that is, to provide real incentive for small business to go ahead and create jobs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be coming up for International Women's Day because once again Opposition members are having their token debate about their concerns for women. What they fail to recognise in the One Nation statement, of course, is that anything that benefits the community benefits women.I had always assumed that women were part of the community. However, from hearing the debate from the Opposition side today, one would think that they were a special gender set aside; that we should in fact be targeting or applying quotas on the 800,000 jobs that we are going to create.
—You know that is not in our nature.

—Then why, Senator, were you asking us to tell you how many jobs there were going to be. It would appear that the Opposition wanted us to set quotas. The Opposition also wants to talk about the two million people that it is trying to employ but, again, it is obviously going to set aside a certain number for women. Now, the Opposition really has to make sure that it knows what it is doing.

PARA.TAB: I get the very distinct impression from the Opposition side today that it is suggesting that we should put on quotas. I would answer that by saying that that is a load of rubbish. Maybe that is a misapprehension on my part but I have certainly gained that impression from the Opposition's debate today. The Opposition should clarify whether or not it is talking about imposing quotas. One cannot get away from the fact that 800,000 jobs would be created, and that anything that benefits the community benefits women.

We have been exposed to a lot of hot air today but I intend to bring some sanity and some common sense to all this. I would like to start off by suggesting that, if the Opposition wants to attack the Labor Government's employment strategies, then we ought to reciprocate by looking at Fightback and at what the Opposition is planning to do.

Of course, it is planning to introduce a voucher system into higher education, and we know that that will disadvantage many people. It is also going to cut labour market expenditure by $140m. Now, what is that going to do for unemployed women? It is not going to do anything for the women and it is certainly not going to do anything for the youth of this country.
The Jobsearch program and wages subsidies will be replaced by Austrain, under which long term unemployed people will be forced to accept jobs for less than award wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ausslave.

—Ausslave is very correct, Senator Cook. I would suggest that some of these areas that the Opposition wants women to go into—and, presumably, they are the lower paid areas—would see them living on an income well below that on which people would normally be expected to live.

PARA.TAB: We also would expect that this will encourage employers—unscrupulous employers—to actually sack people and try to employ more people under Austrain because that would reduce their budgets. That is not an issue that the Opposition cares to canvass terribly much. The Opposition ignores the fact that, where there are several different wage structures operating, including the youth wage, in some industries when people reach the ripe old age of 18 it is not uncommon for employers to put them off because it is cheaper to employ someone who is under that age. Do not tell me that this will not happen with Austrain, because I jolly well believe it will.

The Jobtrain program of short term vocational training courses will be cut by $56m. The Skillshare program will be required to become self-funding over a period of time. If we have a Skillshare program that is operating in an area that is affluent and has a lot of business, then people will be okay. However, it will not be possible to make totally self-funding the areas that Senator MacDonald wanted to talk about—but did not address, of course—namely, the rural and remote areas which are not as affluent. That is just a straight-out attack on anybody who is unfortunate enough to be unemployed and needing assistance.

The Commonwealth Employment Service will be abolished. Its activity testing function will be transferred to the Department of Social Security. The Opposition does not tell us that it is going to increase staff numbers. The job replacement activities will be predominantly privatised or contracted out, which means that those in the business will be able to do the picking and choosing, and it will be Caesar judging Caesar.

The labour market program administration will be devolved to local employment boards. I have no problem with local employment boards but there have to be some controls on them. I have concerns about areas I have visited where, whenever groups want to talk about employment in their area, all the administration wants to do is either put people back working on the roads, building roads—and as we have heard from the Opposition, that is all male or predominantly male, which is a load of rubbish—or cotton chipping and those sorts of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the package is all about—building roads.

—Not the sorts of roads that these people are talking about, and I will move on to that. Let me continue by saying that student financial assistance expenditure would be cut. There are lots of things there to help the unemployed, to help people get employment.
—What about tourism?

—I would like to turn to tourism because one of the areas that is getting a lot of assistance in the One Nation package is hospitality and tourism. We need to remember that 70 per cent of employees in that area are women. I would hasten to add that somewhere around 30 per cent of those are in management positions. They are not, as we have heard from the Opposition, all down making the beds, but they are in important areas of management.

PARA.TAB: We also need to recognise that this has been the big growth industry in this country in the last ten years. Last year we saw a job growth in this area of 50,000 people. That is quite a large number. In the next decade we are expecting that 15 per cent of all jobs will be in this hospitality industry. That is one in six jobs.We have made a significant contribution to tourism in this package. That has been totally ignored by the Opposition.

I might also add, while on the subject of tourism, that ten years ago less than 5 per cent of chefs were female. Now, 40 per cent of the apprentice chefs are female. I think that is a significant statistic. It shows that women are entering male-dominated, male-oriented professions.

Also in tourism, in order to increase new projects, the amortisation rate on tourism income producing buildings will change from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. We have also changed the depreciation rates. There is no recognition of this at all by honourable senators opposite, because that does not suit them. But, of course, that affects employment in that industry.

While I am talking about tourism, I suggest that people think about what the GST will do to tourism, bearing in mind that most tourist facilities are small businesses, small employers, and therefore are not paying payroll tax. They will be hit by the GST. I have here an advertisement which appeared in the papers over Christmas for the Hyatt complex of hotels. It is very interesting to look at the prices. One knows precisely what one is going to pay in Adelaide, Perth and Sydney, but in Auckland one will pay NZ$172 plus 12.5 per cent GST. Of course, 12.5 per cent was not enough GST for New Zealand and it has gone up to 15 per cent. But that is the sort of thing that would happen. Every bill like this that one would get would have a GST stuck on it, and that would have a major impact.

We also heard about small business today. I suggest that the majority of people in small businesses are women. Small business does not pay payroll tax. Yet we heard what a wonderful relief it was going to be for small business that it would not have to pay payroll tax. Small businesses already do not pay payroll tax. We also need to look at the impact of GST upon small business. We currently have about 70,000 businesses paying wholesale sales tax. But, with the introduction of GST, it would be at least 10 times that number—and most of the people affected would be small business people.

That would increase their costs and their overheads because they would need to have somebody available actually able to help them with their GST, because it would be an extra workload. They would have to document it as it came in; they would have to document it as it went out. That, of course, would be a big impost upon small business, but that is completely forgotten by Opposition senators, as one would expect from them; they are selective in terms of what they talk about. I suggest also that if people want to know about the impact of GST upon women and small business, they should talk to small business operators in New Zealand. The small business operators from New Zealand that I have spoken to are grossly concerned about—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been over there?

—No, I have been talking to the ones that have got out because they know that the situation is just so bad. The things that we are doing for small business are: a substantial increase in capital gains tax relief; a three-month extension for the 1991-92 company tax payments for small business; no increase until 1994-95 for the prescribed minimum superannuation levy for businesses with payrolls of $500,000 or less; and a tripling of funding support to $12m for assisting small and medium enterprises to enter export markets through export access programs. And that is not helping small business! It is an absolute furphy to suggest that this Government is not concerned about small business, the largest employer of people in this country. Those are the things that we are doing.

PARA.TAB: I would like to suggest that, in looking at employment, we have to look also at education. We have seen a dramatic increase in the last eight years in the number of girls staying on at high school and the number of women entering university. The numbers of female entrants to university and female graduates are greater than for men. Those women, of course, must take their place in management as they work their way up in industries. Senator Sowada talked about sex segregation. That is nothing new to us people who have worked with the women's movement for a long time. It is something that was around for the 27 years out of 30 that honourable senators opposite were in government, and they did nothing about it. We have increased the number of women who have access to education and who are coming out with degrees and other qualifications that will enable them to get into the senior levels of management. That is certainly something that we are working on.

It was suggested also that road and rail measures—such as the initiatives for Brisbane-Sydney-Melbourne-Adelaide and beyond—will not help women. I suggest that people should think about what else goes on when something is being built. It is not just the people who manhandle the sleepers and the iron rails; it is also those people who actually do the surveying and the drafting of the plans. The women steelworkers at BHP in Wollongong—who managed after many years of struggle to beat the discriminatory qualification criteria for access to this sort of work with BHP—will benefit because the steel from BHP will go into those railway lines. If that is not helping women, I do not know what is.

Senator Macdonald made a cheap shot about better cities. Women do want to live in better urban areas. What about town planners? There are women in that profession. What about structural engineers and things like that? There are women in these professions. What about draughtspeople, clerks, surveyors, drivers, security officers? Women are in all those ranks and they will all benefit from this program.

I am running out of time. In respect of superannuation, all I can say to Senator Newman is that I suggest she read the Australian Financial Review of 21 February, because Dr Hewson has promised to review the Opposition's superannuation plan. It has not even implemented it yet, but he is going to review it. Brilliant!

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you put that furphy around; you are wrong.

—Senator Newman should read the paper. I only point to what the paper says. I am glad also that Senator Newman wanted to mention the ASU meeting last week. It is a pity that she could not have stayed longer and heard the whole of the issue.
—I had to speak to the veterans that you have done in the eye.

—What we were talking about was child-care. Of course, I would like everyone to be aware of the Liberals' approach to child-care. They are still looking at some of these things, such as how they will do their tax deductions and tax rebates. Senator Newman also sees nothing wrong with Mercedes Benz owners having assistance with child-care. I do not either, if there is an unlimited bucket of money. But we have a restricted budget, and I know that it is important that we target child-care to those people who need it, not to those who have a Mercedes Benz. It is very important.

PARA.TAB: We have also heard honourable senators opposite saying that women living in remote rural areas will have better access to general and specialist health care. There is an oversupply of doctors in this country. What they are not addressing is how we get the doctors out of the cities into the country. There is none of that in the Opposition's policy today. We have also heard honourable senators opposite talking about doctors' charges. They would just let the AMA set its own charges. That is Caesar judging Caesar. This is the sort of thing that this Opposition wants to do for women—not a thing that is going to help them. We have seen in One Nation the outline of a program which cares for women and the whole community.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This urgency motion was very specific. It referred to the failure of the Prime Minister's package to give any attention to the employment needs of Australian women. In two hours we have seen three Government speakers who have had little or nothing to say to defend their package because there was little or nothing to say to defend it. So what did they do? They spent their time diverting attention by trying to attack the long term reform measures of the Opposition's Fightback package—a decade of reform; 700 pages of very specific detail. But the Government is not prepared to give us that sort of detail, and certainly the women of Australia have recognised that.

PARA.TAB: This debate is not even seen as important by the Government. There has been no ministerial representation in this debate, and that is a wicked shame. Over half the people in Australia are women, this is a major issue for women, and no Minister is prepared to take part in the debate. There has not even been a man in the Labor Party who has been prepared today to debate this important issue of women's employment needs.

Every time that I raise in debate in this Parliament issues of particular importance to women, the Labor Party fields an all female team. It marginalises debates to the women's sandpit. The Government does not regard women's issues as being mainstream. It parades its pro-female rhetoric, but its performance is rotten. Women are locked out of education, they are thrown out of work, they have not been supported in the work force by the Government's union mates—and let us remember that this Government is full of former unionists who have done little or nothing to advance the cause of women—and this Government is failing them in all the practical ways that they need help.

The `One Day' package that Mr Keating released last week is just that—one day, passed into history, or, `One day we might help you if we are really pressed for an election and we have to perform'. This Government is failing women—one job—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two nations.
—Two nations; perhaps that is a more accurate way of saying it. This Government has failed women, particularly in terms of their employment needs.
