DEBATE.TITLE: IMPROVING CLIENT SERVICE DELIVERY IN THE DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston—I raise a point of order. Are there any ministerial statements?
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—No, there are no ministerial statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a ministerial statement by the Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, relating to improving client service delivery in the Department of Social Security, to move a motion and to make a brief statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the document

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement by the Minister is described as being about the more efficient and effective delivery of client services by the Department of Social Security. That is an objective that we would all endorse. Indeed, it is highly desirable that the quality of service should continue to improve.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, when one examines this statement closely, one sees that it would seem to have a lot more to do with improved job creation programs for the public sector and for the staff of the Department than with effectively improving service to clients. Probably the ultimate test of that is that in various places the statement deals with how the Department has coped well with the pressures of increasing numbers of people using DSS services. It says that there will be significant reductions in demand, and points to a number of services currently performed that will no longer need to be dealt with within regional offices because they can now be dealt with by a new service involving 11 teleservice centres being created throughout the nation each staffed by between 80 and 150 people.

Having said all that, when one would have expected that the end result would be the more efficient delivery of services and, therefore, less demand on current staffing, we find that there will be an increase in cost for the service. Therefore, one is entitled to conclude that this is really more of a recipe for an explosion in the delivery of services and an increase in the number of people to provide them than a recipe to ensure that clients are better served than they presently are.

The statement envisages a significant expansion in the number of social workers and financial and investment service officers. It even contemplates spending a lot of time and effort in going out and drumming up business for the youth homeless allowance. I do not think any of us would argue that there are not quite a number of people in the community who are in desperate circumstances as a result of their domestic backgrounds and other factors causing them to be both young and homeless. However, there is absolutely nothing to suggest that a solution to the problem is, as Senator Richardson has portrayed it in the past, to embark on a massive advertising campaign to try to make people more aware of the fact that they are entitled to be paid.

I do not see this statement doing anything more than simply justifying the retention of current staffing numbers. It is, therefore, very disappointing that the most we get in terms of efficiency is some vacuous statement about the cost being $15m. In the longer term, the cost will be offset by productivity savings. If the Government were serious, it would have gone into a lot more detail. Therefore, I have to say that one should not at all assume that this will result in better service delivery.

One only has to look at the Child Support Agency to discover probably the most grotesque example of service delivery gone wrong. It is probably the greatest fiasco in the history of Public Service delivery. It is replete with injustices and complaints—complaints of clients being ignored; being shunted between offices; being told to ring back; not being able to make contact in the first place; not being understood when they do make complaints; and being treated in a cavalier fashion. In view of that experience, one would have to be very wary of the effectiveness of this new scheme.

I note that it has been trialled in Brisbane and that it is based on experience in the United States. I would have thought that we were entitled to many more indications of the safeguards which will be applied instead of it serving as a basis for simply jacking up the rates across the board, as this statement indicates will happen. It does not in any way follow that because the Government is restructuring the Department in this fashion, it is justified in creating new tiers and promoting people to higher levels. That is no doubt one of Senator Cook's favourite ways of avoiding award limitations.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—It is. It is simply redefining the job. Employees cannot be paid any more than the award so they are promoted to higher levels.
—I am being very kind to you this afternoon and you gratuitously pick on me. That is unfair.

—I do not do it unfairly or unjustly. I simply say that it is a time-honoured technique, when limited in terms of wage increases, to promote people to higher levels. That is what seems to be under way here. If one were serious about it, one would be talking about greater efficiencies—about reducing the need for people at the coalface by substituting them with 1,200-odd people who will be answering telephones.

PARA.TAB: I hope that what we see out of this restructuring is a better quality of service. I certainly look forward to the performance indicators that will be tabled during the Budget sittings. I do not understand why they could not have already been tabled so that we would have some benchmark against which to measure these teleservice delivery centres. Therefore, the statement has all the hallmarks of expedience, of a new Minister being captured by the Public Service Union and, when we judge it against the standards that currently operate, of being a program much more in the interests of staff than clients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely concerned that this statement did not appear on the Order of Business—the Red—today. I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) to explain to the Senate why this statement, made in the House of Representatives by Dr Blewett, was not also brought to the Senate. As he would know, such statements are delivered in both places. The Minister, Dr Blewett, certainly thinks that it is an important statement. I believe that this is just a downgrading of the Senate by the Government. If the Minister believes that that is a legitimate thing to do, I would like him to explain to us why it has been done.

PARA.TAB: Many honourable senators in this place are particularly interested in the social security portfolio; we also have our shadow Minister for social security in this place. The Australian Democrats do not have a representative in the House of Representatives and, as such, therefore, could be completely unaware that such a statement had been presented to the Parliament. I ask the Minister to explain to the Senate why the Government has taken this action, which is totally different from the traditional and polite method of informing the Senate when a statement has been made.
As I say, the Minister, Dr Blewett, believes this is a very important statement. We only have to read his paper, where he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The measures I am announcing today will radically alter the way the DSS does business, bringing immediate and long term benefits for both clients and staff.
He goes on:
Teleservice Centres—
and this is the new service centre that is to be set up—

will revolutionise the way the DSS does business. They will reduce the need for clients to travel to DSS offices and enable staff to provide more time and assistance when personal visits are required.

I just fail to understand why the Minister did not have the statement listed on the Order of Business and I ask him if he would later explain to us why. This is a costly exercise. I note that $15m of taxpayers' money is to be spent. Again I put to the Minister: why were we not informed that this was to take place?

PARA.TAB: I am particularly concerned about privacy in this area. Just recently—indeed, last month—6,000 people were sent information about banking accounts, security payments, income investments and assets. They received all sort of details relating to other people. The information was sent to the wrong people. In New South Wales 6,000 people were sent incorrect information—not their information, but information that related to strangers.

The Privacy Commissioner has suggested that the Department could introduce more human intervention in computer printer runs of 10,000 or 20,000. He said that this would require an employee to select letters randomly, at regular intervals, to ensure that errors do not occur. Has the Minister introduced this? I would be most interested to know whether he has.

But that has not been the only occasion that this has happened. Last year, when Senator Richardson was Minister, 400 people were sent incorrect information. We have this continual problem in the Department of Social Security. We now have a new Minister. A dreadful mistake, a dreadful error, has been made under the new Minister in that 6,000 people sent the wrong information. The Minister in his paper says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . teleservice centres will be based on strict rules for the positive identification of callers and for client confidentiality and privacy.

That sounds pretty good, but what on earth are the strict rules for confidentiality? We are not told what they are. The Minister also says that the caller will need to satisfy proof of identity procedures before any information is provided by the DSS operator. But again in the Minister's statement there is no detail whatsoever of how this is to come about.

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Commissioner has made some suggestions about how the Department could fix the problems it has already. We are to move into a new telephone service where I think privacy will be a much greater problem. The Minister, Dr Blewett, says that the Department has worked very hard to find the cause of and to rectify the 6,000 wrongly directed pieces of information. But he has not said in his paper what action was taken, whether the Department has accepted the Privacy Commissioner's recommendation or whether it has done virtually nothing at all. The Privacy Commissioner also suggested, as we all know, that compensation would be appropriate in some cases. But the Minister ruled that out very specifically, saying that it was not appropriate.

A problem that I have with our new Minister is that I do not believe that philosophically he has the sort of concern about privacy that should be the ultimate objective of a Minister who is in charge of the Department of Social Security. Senator Richardson used to tell us how concerned he was; we now have Dr Blewett telling us how concerned he is. But for the 6,000 people who received inaccurate information—who received very accurate information about other people but not about their own circumstances—it was not acceptable. We all remember how Dr Blewett carried on. We remember him saying, `This will not happen again' and `We will take action'. He has not explained in his paper what action he has taken to make sure that this does not happen again.

We only have to look at that Minister's history to see how genuine and sincere he is in his comments about this type of occurrence being unacceptable. We only have to go back six or seven years to a statement he made at the ALP State Conference in South Australia. This is what Dr Blewett said at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a Socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before individual rights. . . we shouldn't get too hung up as Socialists on privacy, because privacy, in many ways is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

That was not very long ago. And I do not believe this Minister has changed his general philosophy as a socialist one iota—not one iota. He has carried on in a way to make people believe that he is interested in privacy. But in the confidentiality of an ALP conference, he really made it very clear that socialists should not get too hung on up on privacy `because privacy, in many ways is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property'. I do not think any of the Social Security recipients whose information was sent to someone else would agree with him.

PARA.TAB: It is because of my concern that the Minister of this portfolio lacks all credibility when it comes to privacy that this statement is of great interest to me. The teleservice centres will, I believe, create even more problems for privacy. I would like to be assured that privacy will be able to be maintained if these teleservice centres are to be brought in. Also, I would like to know how privacy is to be maintained. As I say, there is absolutely nothing whatsoever in this paper about privacy or how privacy will be protected. This subject is only talked about in very general terms. I believe that the Senate needs to have the detail before we will go along with anything that the Minister is suggesting to us. As I say, the cost will be $15m.

The credibility of this Minister is non-existent when it comes to privacy. We need the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber at the moment, to explain to us how the Department of Social Security is going to enforce the privacy and confidentiality angles that would satisfy us; why this statement was not put on the Order of Business—the red—today; and why the Senate was not entitled to at least have the courtesy of the statement being presented in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pertinent that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Blewett) admits in this ministerial statement on the delivery of client services that overall DSS client numbers are expected to continue to rise, at least in the short term. How much worse can this recession get? Already a record 760,000 people are receiving Jobsearch allowance and Newstart allowance, and well in excess of 400,000 are receiving either the disability support pension or the carer's pension.

PARA.TAB: Five million Australians are receiving payments from the Department of Social Security. The fact that the Department is being forced to introduce teleservice, referred to in the ministerial statement, is an indictment of the Government's economic policies. It is proof of the massive human hardship being caused by the recession deliberately engineered by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—the recession he said we had to have. It shows that the Department of Social Security is no longer able to handle the massive increase in welfare recipients, with double digit unemployment and half a million further underemployed Australians. That is what we are looking at; that is the problem the Department is dealing with.

Since the onset of the recession, we have been informed that DSS officers have had to hire security guards; that there has been a significant rise in the number of staff harassment cases; that there has been an ongoing array of bungled DSS mail-outs, to which Senator Walters referred and which I spoke of last night; that DSS regional offices have been defaced; and that DSS officers are having difficulty coping with job stress.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your solution?

—That is a good question. Fightback! is our solution, to create jobs so that we do not have these great queues in Social Security offices. That is our solution, but I will not be diverted from the main course at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Given the great sensitivity of the DSS in making the results from its operational performance monitoring systems available to the public, it is virtually impossible for either the public or for us as politicians to find out how long those queues are, how long people have to wait on the telephone, and how many problems exist when clients actually do get to see Social Security officers.

We have found it very difficult to ascertain whether staff are managing to attain the performance standards set by the Department. Thankfully, the Auditor-General in his report to the Parliament yesterday recommended that standards of timeliness and quality should be made public as soon as is practicably possible. In the statement the Minister says that he will follow through and take up this recommendation.

Given the Minister's estimate that DSS numbers will continue to rise, the Government has been forced to introduce this teleservice system to overcome the queues. I agree wholeheartedly with the objective of reducing the queues but not necessarily with the way in which it is being done. I have doubts whether the teleservice proposal in this ministerial statement has been properly researched and trialled, and whether sufficient consultation with interested and affected parties has been undertaken by the Government.

I have reason to believe that this is a hastily put together initiative. The Department conducted a teleservice trial in Brisbane. This trial redirected telephone calls made to regional offices to a teleservice centre. Obviously the majority of those calls would have been of a general inquiry nature. That is a far cry from the proposed teleservice system which is being put in place and which will undertake many of the day to day administrative duties normally carried out in DSS regional offices.

If it had been ensured that such a major change in the administration of the social security system is to be conducted efficiently and fairly, I would have reasonably expected that significant consultation with relevant people in the community would have been undertaken. I have grave doubts as to whether this has occurred. This change seems to have been sprung on the Parliament; in fact, it was not even tabled in the Senate. That is the attitude of the Government to this House. This information was not even tabled here, where we have the shadow Minister for social security. The Opposition has had to table it. The change was sprung on the Parliament, sprung on the general public, and sprung on the users of the service. I cannot find any mention of this change in the latest annual report of the DSS.

As far as I am concerned, from our side of politics, there have been no efforts to consult parliamentarians, to whom people with concerns about Social Security go. I and many of my colleagues have had people make representations on some of the problems that have been associated with Social Security regional offices. There has been no consultation with us. The change has major privacy and confidentiality implications, as Senator Walters said. But I question the extent of consultation with the Privacy Commissioner and civil liberties groups.

Teleservice also has very important legal implications in terms of evidentiary requirements, but I wonder about the extent of consultation with legal groups. Did DSS consult with welfare groups, self-help groups and community organisations before it announced this change? Did the Department consult with Austel about the implications of a telecommunications-based benefit administration system? What is the extent of the DSS study of similar initiatives in the United States and overseas countries?

In its consultations with all these groups, has DSS pointed out the problems it has identified in relation to this proposal and how it intends to overcome these problems? In an endeavour to answer these questions in the short time we have had—we received the document at 11.30 a.m.—I have done some research. I have made some preliminary inquiries on the degree of consultation that has taken place on the teleservice proposal. The findings are staggering and interesting. ACOSS knew nothing about it, except for seeing a media article reporting Dr Blewett. I was directed to the Welfare Rights Centre in Brisbane, where the trial occurred, by the welfare rights people. That centre advised that 70 per cent of its clients who used the trial teleservice system reported problems with it. I rang the office of the Privacy Commissioner. It was news to the people there; they had never seen it. So I faxed them a copy of the Minister's statement.

The Minister in his statement says that the protection of client privacy has the highest priority in the Department. We have a complex system being introduced, with Department of Social Security officers running around with computers. I applaud Social Security for officers going out to the aged and the infirm—but with a portable computer with information on it? What are the privacy implications of that if the computer is lost or the car is stolen or whatever?

There are never ending claims by Government Ministers that they are constantly liaising with the Privacy Commissioner. I believe that the Privacy Commissioner should be at arm's length from the Government, but not so far away that the Commissioner does not even know what is going on; not so far away that the Privacy Commissioner has to be informed by a member of the Opposition that a paper is being tabled which has some privacy implications and should be commented on by the Privacy Commissioner. When we contacted Beverley Schurr from the New South Wales Council of Civil Liberties, she said she did not have a clue what we were talking about. When we rang Austel, a spokesman there did not have a clue about the proposal either. In fact, I could not find one person with whom the Government had consulted about this important change.

It must not be forgotten that five million Australians will be affected by this change. It is not a paltry number of people. Nearly one-third of our population will be affected by this change. Amongst all those important groups I could find no-one who had been consulted, and the welfare rights group in Brisbane found that 70 per cent of its clients had some concerns about the teleservice trial. It makes me concerned about the proposal the Minister is putting before us.

Australians and this Parliament have a right to know whether the Government has thought through this proposal sufficiently, whether it has consulted with welfare representatives, whether there will be sufficient standards to protect recipients from bureaucratic incompetence, inefficiency and, in some cases—and I must say very limited cases, as the ICAC demonstrated—dishonesty. There is no evidence of any such assurances. Five million Australians are being asked again to trust the Department of Social Security, to take it on face value. They are being asked to trust the same Department that sends to thousands of recipients not their own financial details but details and information about other people. They are being asked to trust a department that sends letters to dead people.

This ministerial statement and the relevant attachment are sadly short on the details of the teleservice system. In fact, rather than explaining how this system will work, the consultation that has occurred and how clients' interests will be protected, it reads more like a public relations document to promote the advantages of the teleservice system. I believe that there will be major teething problems entailed in the introduction of this system—teething problems that this ministerial statement either fails to recognise or, more likely, refused to recognise.

Where do social security clients turn if they find themselves unfairly treated as a result of this teleservice system? Probably they will turn to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal or to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I wonder whether the Social Security Appeals Tribunal or the Ombudsman have been consulted.

I wish to outline some of the teething problems I foresee in the teleservice system. There is the problem of evidence when deciding disputes between DSS and its clients resulting from administrative action that may or may not have been taken as a result of information provided to a teleservice centre. Will clients know to whom they are providing, for example, changes of circumstance and bank account information? What will happen if the DSS officer at the other end of the telephone does not take the action required and a client is overpaid? Whose word will be good? No doubt what might be said is, `I telephoned, I told DSS that my income status had changed, but it is my word against that of the DSS officer that I have made the phone call'. How will that be recorded? How will we know? Will the person concerned be accused of receiving overpayments and of not advising the Department of a change in income status?

What happens if the telephone operator mistakenly actions the wrong file? Will all telephone conversations be taped? How will the record be kept of the fact that a DSS client has contacted the Department? Will clients be informed that if they do not receive written confirmation of the action taken they should immediately contact their DSS regional office? When they make the phone call, how will they be sure that action has been taken on that phone call? At least when they go into the office, somebody fills out a form.

Can Australians be 100 per cent confident that all teleservice operators will have the knowledge and capabilities to handle the wide variety of inquiries they will receive from clients and from would-be clients? After all, it is much easier to hide one's ignorance over the telephone rather than face to face. Can DSS ensure that the client on the other end of the phone is actually the person that they purport to be? How can DSS protect its clients from fraudulent operators who seek to use the teleservice system for their own financial gain?

There are other operational and privacy concerns. Will 100-long queues in DSS offices just be replaced by 100-long telephone queues and constantly engaged numbers? We know of other departments where people spend hours hanging on the end of a telephone. Will people who prefer face to face contact or who are wary about having their benefits administered over the phone still receive the same attention at regional offices that they do now? Or will they be shunted to the back of the queue because they are inquiring about matters which can be directed to teleservice? Will clients, their advocates and politicians for that matter, still be able to ring DSS regional offices? Will they now be forced to go through the teleservice centre regardless of whether their inquiry relates to a matter that can be handled by a teleservice operator?

I am sure that many Australians will be extremely concerned that between 80 and 150 DSS officers in 11 teleservice centres will have access to the files of every DSS client. At the touch of a computer keyboard they will be able to access that information. Many may be even more concerned about DSS officers walking around the streets or driving around in their cars with lap-top computers containing data about untold numbers of DSS clients.

One final important point must be made. This teleservice initiative is really up-market, high technology stuff as far as developing a faceless, heartless bureaucracy is concerned. For years people from all walks of life have criticised Social Security—not always justly—for not caring about its clients and treating them as nothing more than numbers to be herded through the system. I reiterate that that is not always the case. In fact, many people have resorted to voluntary agencies and to religious and to community groups because there is a perception that Social Security does not seem to care about the pain, the hardship and the lack of self-esteem. One wonders whether that will increase as a result of shifting the problem further away from the counter face onto a faceless and impersonal telephone.

This teleservice initiative reveals the direction in which Labor is taking the Department of Social Security in the 1990s—a faceless, heartless assembly line which has the sole task of redistributing public money to the unfortunate victims of what has been the worst recession in 60 years brought upon us by the current Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION (AMENDMENT) BILL 1992
This Bill will amend the child support legislation in a number of respects.

The Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement that there will be an administrative review process available to all persons named in child support assessments who seek to depart from an assessment raised by the Registrar of Child Support. The grounds for departure will be the same as currently available in a formal process to the court.

A further amendment was also announced in the Budget context relating to a one time option for a pensioner custodian to opt for the private collection of amounts assessed by the Registrar. This Bill amends the law to allow this option to be exercised.

A series of amendments will enhance the powers of the Registrar to recover amounts that are due. The power of garnishee will enable debts due to be recovered directly from persons holding money on behalf of a payer who has an outstanding child support debt. A facility is also to be included in the child support legislation which is modelled on a similar provision in the Family Law Act 1975 to enable the Registrar to seek an order from a court to set aside an instrument or disposition which has the effect of reducing or defeating a person's capacity to pay child support. These measures have become necessary to ensure that those persons who do not meet their responsibility at law to provide for their children cannot continue to ignore that responsibility.
In addition the Bill contains a number of other amendments to the existing legislation designed to enhance the working of the scheme.

The child support scheme has brought about a substantial turnaround in the attitude to, and the payment of, child support for children in single parent families since its inception in June 1988. The outcome has been to see disposable incomes of custodial families increased for the benefit of the children.
The detail of the amendments to the legislation I will now outline further assists children in single parent families.
THE ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW PROCESS

The Bill will allow a custodian or a liable parent to have an assessment of child support reviewed free of charge and without legal representation by an independent child support review officer who will be employed by the Registrar for that single purpose. The intention is that the parties be able to have an assessment reviewed in the light of their individual circumstances. This review will be a mandatory first step in the general appeal process allowable under the law. It may be exercised at any time during the currency of any assessment which is effective from and after 1 July 1992, but may only be based on the grounds that are presently set out for appeals to the courts.

If the grounds that are already prescribed exist, it will be possible for a determination to be made by the Registrar departing from the assessment in force in the same fashion as a court can order a departure from an assessment.
Further rights of appeal to the court are retained against determinations that may be made.

Of major importance in this amendment is the proposal to allow and encourage the parties during the course of this mediation and review process, to agree how the amounts of child support, either in the form of periodic or non periodic amounts, should be paid. It has never been the intention of the assessment process or the scheme itself to limit people agreeing to arrangements for the support of their children. The most satisfactory and unobtrusive way is for the parents to agree to those arrangements themselves with, however, appropriate revenue safeguards in place for custodians who are in receipt of an income tested pension, benefit or allowance.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment has an estimated cost of $0.08m in 1991-92, $0.32m in 1992-93 and $0.45m in 1993-94.

SPEECH.PARA: PRIVATE COLLECTION OF MAINTENANCE
At present it is a mandatory requirement that pensioners register for collection by the Child Support Agency an amount of child support that arises from an administrative assessment.

This Bill will end that mandatory requirement and allow a pensioner to choose to have the payments made direct. Pensioners may still choose to register the assessment for collection from the outset if that is their wish. Providing that they report to the Department of Social Security that payments are being made in full under the assessment they may continue to receive the payments due privately and directly. If they report that payments are not being made as required, the Department will then require them, as part of the reasonable action for maintenance guidelines, to register the assessment for collection and once registered it must remain registered until the liability ceases.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: The estimated cost of this measure to the Agency is $0.60m in 1991-92, $1.2m in 1992-93 and outyears offset by estimated savings to Department of Social Security of $0.48m in 1991-92, $2.98m in 1992-93, $2.42m in 1993-94 and $2 6m in 1994-95.

SPEECH.PARA: ENHANCEMENT OF THE RECOVERY POWERS OF THE REGISTRAR.

The methods of collection of amounts due each month to the Registrar are either by deduction at source of income for salary and wage earners or by direct payment to the Registrar from those employees for whom the Agency has not been able to identify an employer or all those liable parents who are not employees for the purposes of the taxation laws.

The power to recover amounts of child support that have not been paid to the Registrar when due is presently limited to actions in the court and by intercepting refunds of tax due on assessment under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

This Bill will enhance the power to recover overdue amounts by making provision for the Registrar, by notice in writing, to require a person who is holding money on behalf of the person who has a child support related debt, to pay so much of the money that is held in satisfaction of the debt that is due. The provision will also provide the scope for the Registrar to require amounts that would, in other circumstances, be deemed to be salary and wages, to be garnisheed from time to time to the extent necessary to pay amounts of child support that are due to the Registrar.

There are other occasions when the Registrar must act quickly to ensure an opportunity to collect amounts due is not lost. Very often the Registrar becomes aware of amounts being held for the liable parent by a third person, a settlement is due in which the liable parent is to receive a cash amount or of the existence of cash in an account at a financial institution. When all efforts to collect have failed, or in the judgment of the Registrar, it would be appropriate to garnishee funds held it will be possible to do so administratively without seeking an order of the court.

Allied to this change is a complementary change to allow the Registrar to garnishee amounts from funds held in Australia for persons who have a child support debt in Australia who, for the time being, are not in Australia.
These measures should result in an improved rate of receipt of child support for the benefit of children where these opportunities are detected.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment is at no cost but an unquantifiable reduction in Social Security outlays could follow.

SPEECH.PARA: THE OTHER AMENDMENTS
CONSENT ORDERS TO BE SUBJECT TO THE SCRUTINY OF THE COURT.

An appeal may be lodged with a court concerning the outcome of an assessment, and, after passage of this Bill, against a determination on an administrative assessment made by the Registrar. The present legislation provides that the court must state reasons for making an order which are then required to be entered in the records of the court. This does not apply to orders made by consent and it is therefore possible that pensioners can arrange to depart from an assessment without the new arrangements being subject to the scrutiny of the court. This could undermine the thrust of the legislation in this area. A determination, if any, made by the Registrar will also have to be considered in this way for pensioner custodians.

The Bill will therefore amend the law to require consent departure orders entered into by pensioners to be subject to the scrutiny of the court as is the case when the court has itself been asked to make an order.
Similar amendments are made to other parts of the law to complement this change.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: There is no cost in this amendment but it ensures Social Security outlays are protected.

SPEECH.PARA: PAYMENTS MADE OUTSIDE THE AGENCY ARRANGEMENTS

Provisions exist to allow the Registrar to take into account payments directly between the parties against the liability to pay the Registrar. This is a popular provision and is much used by clients of the Agency, even though it is the cause of problems from time to time. It is a provision which allows, in special circumstances, the payer to support the children directly as the need arises. The provision is limited in scope and this Bill will open up the range of payments that can be brought to account by the Registrar. In particular payments to third parties from which the custodian and the children receive a benefit will, after the agreement of the parties, and if the Registrar is satisfied, become allowable as credits against the liability to the Registrar.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment will have no cost but an unquantifiable reduction in Social Security outlays could follow.

SPEECH.PARA: ENFORCEMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT DEBTS WHEN PAYER IS NOT PRESENT IN AUSTRALIA.

Child support debts registered with the Agency are debts due to the Commonwealth and this fact has caused difficulty with enforcement in some European countries. They have not been prepared to enforce debts in these circumstances. A minor machinery type change is made to separate the concepts of who is due to be paid child support and who may receive i.e., collect the amounts that are paid in these cases. The change ensures in law the money is due to the payee but it is to paid through the Commonwealth acting as agent for the payee.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment will have no cost but an unquantifiable reduction in Social Security outlays could follow.

SPEECH.PARA: SETTING ASIDE TRANSACTIONS TO DEFEAT CAPACITY TO PAY CHILD SUPPORT.

A provision exists in the Family Law Act 1975 to enable a court to set aside transactions, whether already made or proposed to be made, the effect of which is to reduce or defeat an order of the court in a maintenance matter.

This Bill inserts a similar provision in the child support legislation to ensure that the Agency can, in any proceedings under the child support legislation before the court or, by separate application to the court, have the court set aside such transactions, the effect of which has been or will be to reduce or defeat the payer's capacity to pay child support at all or the amount due under any liability that has been established.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment is at no cost but an unquantifiable reduction in Social Security outlays could follow.

SPEECH.PARA: ELECTIONS TO END A CHILD SUPPORT LIABILITY

The Bill also proposes to remove the ability of pensioners to elect to end the liability of the non custodial parent who is required to pay child support. Because assessment of child support is now mostly an administrative process there is a need to have an administrative method of ending a liability. An example arises where a couple reconciles and it takes no more than an election under the appropriate section in a letter to the Registrar to end the liability. However, pensioners may be unduly influenced by the non custodian to use this election to simply end their legal liability, or of their own volition pensioners might want to end the liability of the non custodian so as to maximise their pension entitlement.

The ability to elect to end the liability is to be withdrawn for a pensioner under this section, but, in the event that a liability should be properly ended and the custodian is a pensioner, there are separate provisions called terminating events under which the law operates automatically to end the liability in all of the likely circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Financial impact: This amendment is at no cost but will ensure Social Security outlays are protected.

SPEECH.PARA: OVERLAPPING PROVISIONS

This Bill will eliminate the need for the Agency to have to offset liabilities that arise, one against the other, when there is both an assessment and an order of the court or an agreement for payment of maintenance in force for the same child for the same period. The offsetting process is now believed to be unnecessary and the new provision to be inserted in its place will have the effect of terminating liabilities under any order or agreement if an assessment has been issued for the same child and for the same period.
Financial impact: This amendment is at no cost.
CHILDREN SUBJECT TO A CHILD WELFARE LAW

Finally, the Bill extends eligibility for administrative assessment of child support to parents and relatives of children who are the subject of a child welfare law providing those children are in the care, custody or guardianship of the parent or relative. This amendment will take effect on a State by State basis as each State amends their referral of powers legislation i.e. Commonwealth Powers (Family Law—Children) Acts.
Financial impact: This amendment is at no cost.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Bill provides for the social security measures announced in the Prime Minister's February 1992 Economic Statement. One aspect also applies to certain veterans.

It is recognised that the current recession has made life more difficult for families with children and for those on a pension or benefit who have to pay rent. With this in mind the Government is keen to target special assistance to these groups.

The first of these initiatives is a one-off payment of a family allowance bonus to all those in Australia who receive a routine family allowance payment on or in respect of 2 April 1992. The bonus will be an amount of $125 for a family with one child; $175 for a family with two children; $200 for a family with three children; $225 for a family with four children; and $250 for a family with five or more children. A one-off amount of $125 will be made for each child in an approved care organisation who attracts payment of family allowance to the organisation on 2 April 1992. The family allowance bonus is payable only to those whose family allowance is usually paid to an account in Australia or otherwise is paid in Australia.

It will be possible for the Department of Social Security to recover any overpayments of this family allowance bonus but it will not be subject to deductions by the Department to help satisfy any other debt a person may owe to the Department.
This one-off payment will prove useful to those who have dependent children and will also provide an early stimulus to the economy as the money is spent and enters the economy.

The second of these initiatives is to increase the child amounts paid to certain pensioners, beneficiaries and recipients of family allowance supplement. The Government has decided to increase these amounts by $3 a child per week except for a child who attracts a frozen rate of payment. Those who will benefit from this initiative will be:
.all recipients of family allowance supplement except to the extent that the rate includes a frozen amount;
.all social security pensioners and beneficiaries with dependent children whose rate of pension or benefit includes a child add-on except to the extent that a child add-on is a frozen rate; and
.all veterans' affairs service pensioners with dependent children whose rate of pension includes a child add-on except to the extent that a child add-on is a frozen rate.
These changes will take effect on the first payday after 2 April 1992.

As a part of the legislation to be introduced shortly to bring about the integration of family allowance, family allowance supplement and pension and benefit child add-on amounts, this $3 increase will become a permanent part of the family payment rates. Speaking in the terms of the current legislation, the intention is to increase from 15% to 16.2% of the combined pensioner couple maximum basic rate the benchmark used in indexing family payments in respect of children aged under 13 and from 20% to 21.2% of the combined pensioner couple maximum basic rate the benchmark for indexation of family payments in respect of children aged 13 to 15 years on 1 January each year.
This is another payment targeted to groups which, because of the cost of bringing up children, the Government has judged to be in particular need at the moment.

The third initiative involves the abolition of all rent assistance waiting periods for social security recipients except those waiting periods which apply to single beneficiaries without dependent children who are aged below 18. In the 1991 budget it was decided that the existing 26 week waiting periods should be reduced to 18 weeks as of 20 March 1992. This new decision supersedes the 1991 Budget decision for all except those aged single beneficiaries under 18. Some beneficiaries will still serve a de facto waiting period where the standard one week waiting period, or other longer waiting periods, for payment of a social security benefit are involved.

This package of social security measures continues this Government's proud record of increasing social security and veterans' payments required by those most in need. This package is a compassionate response to the current recession and will help to stimulate economic activity by injecting $317 million into the economy in April. Ongoing extra expenditure will be $65 million for the rest of the current financial year, $290 million in 1992-93, $301 million in 1993-94, $299 million in 1994-95 and $304 million in 1995-96.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

The atmosphere on the site is one of intimidation. The union shop stewards, the people who control the site, basically make anyone who is not a member of the union feel like an interloper. Quite frankly, when one leaves a construction site anywhere in a capital city in Australia, it is like a breath of fresh air because one is back again in a free world.

Entering construction sites around Australia is basically like stepping into a communist nation where people's individual rights, and certainly the rights of people who are not members of unions, are repressed. One only has to ask the surveyors, those who enter construction sites as couriers or anyone who is not a member of the union what it is like to walk into a construction site to learn that it is like crossing the border into an eastern European country or Cuba. People's rights are infringed, they feel intimidated, and it is virtually the same wherever they go.

The long term effects of this on Australia in the 1990s should be remembered; they are not obvious. Australia had a construction boom. We had a chance to develop some management practices and factor competitive advantages in our region of the world. Because we were doing so much construction we had a tremendous opportunity to develop an advantage in our international competitiveness in the area of construction. However, as a result of the industrial relations provisions and the way that the unions behaved in concert, almost in conspiracy, with the major construction firms in Australia, we ended up with a situation where Australia's construction industry by and large is now not competitive in the south-east Asian and Asia-Pacific region. It is an industry that I suggest to the Parliament and the Senate could have had great export potential for Australia in the 1990s—an era when we need export opportunities.

Korea is a great example of a nation that has developed a competitive edge in the area of construction management and project management. It is exporting those talents to the rest of the south-east Asian region. We have lost an enormous amount of our potential advantage in being able to export the expertise that we have developed in that area. Basically, the project managers and the construction firms did not have the flexibility that they needed to learn to manage properly. Most of the flexibility was taken out of their hands by the union movement and the union thugs who control that movement.

The export of materials could also have flowed from developing that competitive advantage. We could have used Australian construction materials such as the granite that is being mined up in the north-west of Western Australia and on the Nullarbor. The mined granite and other building materials could have been exported to those whom we exported our management expertise.

Australia has a very professional, competitive and dynamic interior design business. Interior designers go into the empty shells of buildings and fit them out with partitions, furnishings and so forth. It is another downstream, value added industry that could have followed in the footsteps of our construction management and project management expertise, had we had been able to export it to the south-east Asian region.

That is not to say that that is not happening at the moment. There are certainly some architects, interior designers and construction project managers who are able to get into the rapidly developing Asia-Pacific region. They are forced to do so due to the total lack of work in Australia which stems from the recession caused by Senator Cook and his Government. They are making progress overseas, but the architects and builders that I have been speaking to in the last few weeks say that their impact has been very small.

I turn to some of the work practices on building sites that are still happening today as I speak and which need reforming. They have not been faced up to and will not be faced up to until we get rid of the no ticket no start principle, union monopoly of power on construction sites and centralised control over the work practices and terms and conditions of employment on building sites around Australia. As all my colleagues have mentioned—Senator Durack said it in his address and Senator Crane and Senator Walters reinforced it—until the monopoly of control over labour on construction sites is removed, no other problems will be solved.

It is important for the community to realise what happens on building sites. As I said, it is like crossing no-man's-land to get into the building sites in Australia because of the hoardings around them. Most members of the Australian community are sick and tired of hearing about the sorts of work practices we have on our construction sites, they just do not care any more or they do not find out about them because they all take place behind those hoardings.

Some practices would appal people. Some awards say that construction must stop if it starts raining. That is probably quite sensible if men are 30 storeys up on the Central Park site or the QV1 site and they are trying to move steel or something else around a floor slab. It can get slippery and dangerous in the rain, and there is a safety issue for sure. That is probably a sensible place to start, but on construction sites around Australia it does not take a shower or a rainstorm to get people to stop working; it takes a few drops of rain falling on the newspaper of someone sitting down having a cup of tea for the call, `Right, all out; let's stop'. Then there is a four hour waiting period in which it is decided whether that rain was a passing shower or perhaps even a seagull flying over the guy's newspaper and those on site go back to work. That may also be sensible.

But to take it a step further, if the people sitting in their air-conditioned sheds waiting to decide whether it is going to be a rainy day are rained on, if they have to go to another part of the site during a four-hour waiting period, then the whole site closes down for the entire day. That has happened on Perth construction sites for the past few years, and I presume it has happened in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and every other construction site around the place. Although the people who are sitting in the amenity shed waiting to see whether or not a shower passes may be approached by a project manager or an officer of the construction firm who says, `Look, we'll give you an umbrella so that you can get from your amenities shed to wherever you are going and keep yourselves dry', they still close the whole site down for the entire day. One can imagine the enormous amount of money that is tied up in a quarter of a billion dollar building site by these delays—the capital equipment, the crane hire and the concrete.

Another example concerns employees who are asked to continue work by transferring to air-conditioned areas on a building site to continue work. All employees go home if they have to pass through an area that is not air-conditioned. On many building sites it is impossible to air-condition the lifts. An employee working in an air-conditioned area on, say, floor 21 of a construction site may be asked to go up to floor 30 to do some more work—and that would be quite reasonable as it is another air-conditioned area. It might be a hot day but the employee works in an air-conditioned environment like everyone else in the world. If he is required to jump in an unconditioned lift for 2 1/2 minutes to go up to the thirtieth floor to continue his work, it is a case of all out, the site closes down and, of course, money is lost.

Of course, another outrageous situation concerns a situation in which a courier delivering, say, another set of rivets to a site is not allowed to take the rivets off his truck unless he is a member of the BLF or the Building Workers Industrial Union, or whatever the case may be. It is quite outrageous and quite an infringement of the courier's individual rights and freedoms. He cannot unload his own truck if he is not a member of this union. It is a case of no ticket, no start, not only for the construction workers but for other people who come on to the site.

There are a couple of other things that I would like to mention. There are excessive demands when it comes to things like protective clothing. A recent case in Perth involved employees who needed to wear sunglasses when working outside in the bright sunlight. This was a quite reasonable demand. Most people in industry who need sunglasses—for example, airline pilots—go out and buy them themselves. But not in the building industry. The unions say that the construction firm has to supply them—not just any sunglasses, but the award insists that they have to be Bolles. So one goes down to a boutique and buys Bolle sun glasses for all one's construction workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you get one of these jobs?
—Yes, it is pretty good stuff. It is pretty hard to get one of those jobs now because there are not many buildings being built any more. Of course, they are demanding moon suits and so forth.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the unions are taking what are called technical issues to absolute extremes. Technical issues are used to disrupt sites when awards, pay increases or some other matters are being negotiated. Some of the issues which have been used to close down entire sites in the last couple of years include examples like the fact that the coat hooks were too close together in the amenities shed; a lunch table was 10 millimetres too short—this excuse was used to close down an entire multi-million dollar construction site in Perth in recent years; insufficient chairs in a lunch room, resulting in a day's strike; a lunch room being demanded for a small team of shop fitters in an established shopping centre; double-time payments for shift work; the rostering of employees taking sickies—instead of just taking sickies when one is sick, the building union actually sets up a roster of when people will take sickies; and shutting down cranes and so forth due to windy conditions which were not windy at all—just that somebody felt a bit of wind go past, probably a bit of wind from a shop steward.

One of the worst aspects of this problem is the total inflexibility in the work force. Account is not taken of the local conditions, the economic climate and what is going on in the community where projects are being built. Rostered days off—of course, one day off every four weeks is another rort—cannot be flexibly handled. An employer cannot align a rostered day off with a weekend; he cannot arrange the week's work. If a concrete pour or some sort of major work is being done on the Monday, he cannot go to the union and say, `Let's have the rostered day off after we've finished this concrete pour' or `after we've finished this slab' or `after we've put the glazing on'. There is absolutely no flexibility.

This is what has to take place. There needs to be flexibility. The managers need to be able to manage. The workers have to be able to become part of a team. It cannot be `us and them'. It cannot be the building owner or the project manager versus the people who are building the building. It all has to a team effort. The construction industry works as a team. We need to have sensible arrangements site by site, building by building, project by project. Flexibility needs to be is built into the terms and conditions of the workers.

Of course, the process that Senator Cook is embarking upon and seeking the Senate's approval through legislation for, is, as I said 15 to 20 minutes ago, a joke and outrageous because it will not change any of this. It will not allow the managers to manage. It will not allow Australia's construction industry to become world competitive. It will not allow us to build buildings to best international practice standards. It will ensure that it will cost Australian industry more to build our buildings than it costs any other nation. It will ensure that, until you get rid of the `no ticket no start' rule and union control of construction sites, the reform that just about everyone in Australia except for the union movement wants just will not take place.

So I conclude by repeating: this legislation is a joke, it is outrageous and it really should be condemned as a farce. We have just spent nine years with an industrial relations system that probably should have been, as I said, reformed under the Fraser Government and it was not. If this Minister is interested in reforming the industry, he should have started nine years ago; and if he is interested in reforming it now, he should look at the real problems—and they are union domination and control; inflexibility; and uncompetitive work practices. He should start there. He should not start by setting up another quango. Australians have had enough quangos, they have had enough government waste, they have had enough of high taxes and they have had enough of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I reiterate what has just been said by Senator Campbell—that the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill really is a charade, a sham and a facade for substantial legislation. It does absolutely nothing about the fundamental problems that the building industry has. It does nothing about competition, proper micro-economic reform or voluntary unionism. It does nothing about breaking the nexus between being compelled to be a member of a union and being allowed to work in this country. It is like collective bargaining, productivity based agreements and micro-economic reforms which are being dragged inexorably from this Government in a very incremental sluggish way which guarantees that we will have a continuing lack of efficiency in the industry.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the building industry, being a largely non-traded sector, is not subject to the efficiency disciplines which result from other competition. It is not subject, naturally, to import competition. The additional costs cast upon the industry due to the various inefficiencies that prevail are passed on to owners and, of course, inevitably, guarantee that there will be a misallocation of resources and this impacts upon the competitiveness of other industries. Some people have estimated that the cost of over-regulation and inefficient regulatory systems within the building industry cost Australians about $1 billion a year. Restrictive work practices will always flourish wherever an industry or government service is protected against competition or where unions have the muscle to keep other workers off their patch.

I suspect that Senator Cook's legislation is a creature of intention to be put in place prior to the findings of the Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales. It is, by any measure, a shallow attempt in the name of economic reform to reduce inefficiency. It is an example of attempts which have given micro-economic reform a bad name. Nothing has been done about either the inflexible industrial relations or the lack of competition in the industry between employees, workers and contractors.

According to a report on big city office construction jobs made last year by the Industry Commission, evidence was provided, albeit in confidence, that annual wages for crane drivers were between $130,000 and $160,000 a year, with dogmen earning $100,000. That is not because of a commercial judgment that a crane driver is worth $160,000. It is not the result of some economic based decision that the value of his contribution manifests itself in $160,000 a year. It is simply the amount of wages that he is able to extract from his employer under the threat of industrial disputation.

One of the fundamental industrial relations problems is the entrenched system of full pay during walk-offs. I think it was Senator Campbell who made some comment about how judgments are made in respect of whether employees continue to work during rain periods. The standard test is that one puts a cigarette paper outside the shed and, if one gets three drops of rain on it, that by definition means it is a wet day and all the workers are off the site.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a newspaper.

—It is a newspaper now, is it? That does not apply only to those who are actually getting wet, those who are exposed to the inclemency of the weather; it includes those who are working on already fully constructed floors. The employer is not able to relocate those employees to other duties or responsibilities. They are able to walk off the site.
—Unless it involves outside contractors.

—That is absolutely right. Of course, we do not have outside subcontractors. This circumstance does not apply in the cottage building industry—the domestic building industry. It applies only in the construction industry where one does not have subcontractors. This business of workers walking off and being on full pay only guarantees the sorts of industrial relations problems that we have.

PARA.TAB: Safety rorting is perhaps one of the very worst abuses that take place. Take this building we are in now. One of the great scandals of the last three decades is that 40 per cent of lost man-time was due to alleged safety issues. It is not without significance that when the Queensland Electricity Commission banned or stopped full pay on stoppages over safety issues, the number of bomb hoaxes suddenly stopped overnight. We have seen the same problem all around Australia. Senator Cook saw the same problem with the casino in Western Australia, where almost daily there were bomb hoaxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was shameful.

—The bomb hoaxes were shameful. It would be more shameful if one could establish that the employees themselves were making phone calls that a bomb was about to explode somewhere on a construction site and then walking off the site for a day or two while the police went through a monotonous, tortuous and difficult search to ascertain whether or not there was a bomb.

PARA.TAB: To my knowledge—and Senator Cook might correct me—there is no other country that pays full wages for walking off in the case of bad weather. In Germany and Sweden workers receive about 65 per cent of their standard pay. In other countries it is between 50 and 75 per cent. In the US it is zero because I think workers in that country have an in-built loading in their pay rates.

One could go on ad nauseam citing all the examples of the litany of abuses that take place—abuses which are inevitable in an incestuous environment where, to be allowed to work, one has to become a member of the union. The unions have divine control over the employers who pass on the costs to the owners. Therefore, we have a dislocation of resources.

This legislation will do absolutely nothing about that; I suspect that it is not intended to do so. Probably it has about the same status as this Government's micro-economic reform—the same status as its productivity clauses in industrial relations agreements. It is very much like the One Nation statement—a token attempt to pretend that something constructive is being done. But until this Government is prepared to accept that there are inherent and fundamental problems in the building industry that require total change, there will be no significant improvements in efficiency, costs or competition. I say with the greatest respect to Senator Cook that this legislation is nothing more than a cynical attempt to purport to be making a change which the Minister and this Government know is not taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Senate is now concluding the debate on the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1991. It has been an extraordinary debate. Many Opposition speakers I have heard have said that they oppose this Bill, and I understand that the Opposition will vote against it. Opposition members have proceeded to lay down a series of incidents or examples to demonstrate why, in their view, there is considerable need for improvement and reform in the building industry.

PARA.TAB: Without accepting all those examples, because many are emotional and highly coloured, I would make the point that nonetheless they support the basic contention of this Government. The building and construction industry in Australia is one of the most significant industries in this country. It is an industry that we have sought to reform over the period of our Government. In fact, we were the only government in Australia that moved in the end to deregister by legislative action the Builders Labourers Federation because of its role in creating industrial disharmony and resorting to illegal tactics in the industry. We did that, and indeed we did it twice.

In recognition of those changes there is a need to go further and build on them to make it a more competitive industry. Yet we have had this extraordinary display from Opposition members in which they say they oppose the Bill but, nonetheless, trot out all the reasons why reform in this industry is necessary.

This is not an industrial relations exercise. It is an industry exercise. The Bill is about reforming the industry. That means, therefore, that it looks at industry development and research and development—the industry spends less on research and development than any other industry in Australia; it looks at training; it looks at how we should sort out regulations which in some senses prevent the efficient operation of the industry; and, of course, because it is complete, it deals with industrial relations too. But it would be wrong to assume that one can solve problems in the industry by simply concentrating on industrial relations matters and that there are some simple, glib industrial relations explanations. There are not. Industrial relations problems reflect the problems of the whole industry and this requires a holistic approach to deal with them.

We are proposing to set up a reform agency which will look at improving productivity in the industry quite significantly, because that needs to be done. We seek to ensure that contracts are delivered on time and on cost. We will promote the building and construction sector in Australia as an export industry. We will engage in innovation by nominating, with the agreement of the parties, demonstration sites or special sites in which new methods of work can be trialled. New ways of doing things can be experimented with so that we can learn how to do things better.

The Bill depends on there being a degree of cooperation in trying to achieve the purpose of reform. What we have heard from the Opposition is that one ought to make war on unions. I would not want to contend that there needs to be no reform on that front, as there does need to be reform. However, I do not think there needs to be the sort of, for want of a better word, reform that the Opposition preaches. Certainly I do not think one can reform the industry by trying to eliminate the trade union movement from it, as the Opposition seems to be arguing here.

The key element of our reform process is that we succeeded in doing something significant before this Bill saw the light of day. We had extensive consultations, ranging over most of last year, with all the industry organisations and with the consumers of the industry. I refer to the Building Owners and Managers Association and the major investors in the industry. We went through that process exhaustively. We achieved an in-principle agreement which they have all signed. They have all committed themselves to the goals of the in-principle agreement—stretch targets, hard goals—set down in black and white.

One of the Opposition's contentions in this debate is that there has been insufficient commitment to this concept from the industry. I do not know what Opposition members have been reading or how they interpret insufficient commitment, but not only is the Commonwealth Government committed to it, but also the signatures of the governments of Victoria, South Australia, the ACT and Western Australia appear on the in-principle agreement. The signature of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the organisation representing the major construction companies in this country, appears on the agreement, as do the signatures of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Metal Trade Industry Association, a number of trade unions involved in the industry, the Building Owners and Managers Association, the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia, the Australian Earthmovers and Road Contractors Federation of Australia and the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Services Association of Victoria. We have a commitment by organisations representing the stakeholders in this industry to arrive at the reform targets that we have set down. This is an example of cooperative reform.

It has been said in this debate that we should have waited until the New South Wales Royal Commission reported. We proposed this initiative—and if there be any question on this point one should refer to the Ministers of Labour Advisory Council agenda in April 1990—to the New South Wales Government before it announced its own Royal Commission. We were first in the ring before the New South Wales Government.

The sad history of the industry has been that over the past 15 or so years there have been 22 separate inquiries into the industry; the Royal Commission is yet another. The trouble with inquiries is that they entertain and inform while they are in currency, but their reports have gathered dust on the shelves of libraries after the inquiries have been completed. The big gap relates to the implementation of recommendations and achievement of reform. We did not want to be in what grew in New South Wales to be partly a political exercise, partly an exercise of scapegoatism and partly an exercise directed at real problems in the industry; and we did not want to be in yet another inquiry. There was no appetite for another inquiry, but an appetite for change, improvement and reform. That is why the organisations have come forward so quickly to commit themselves to the proposal that we have put forward.

Last Wednesday night the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), at about this time, rose in the House of Representatives and put down the One Nation statement. By putting through this legislation, we will position the country to ensure that the massive commitment in that statement to infrastructure development goes ahead in the most efficient way. The Government will commit itself to ensuring that the greenfields agreements necessary for that reform to occur can be in place when the infrastructure developments start.

We are in a flat period of building activity; that is true, and it has been referred to by a number of speakers. This is the time when the structural changes in the industry ought to be made so that the efficiencies can be achieved now, when there is a recognition that work is scarce, and so that the reform proposals, having been achieved, can be presented to would-be investors and this industry can come out of its slump sooner in a new guise and be reborn. That is why it is absolutely essential to move now and not hang back and wait for a royal commission's report, which may or may not make useful suggestions about reform, which may or may not be able to be implemented straight away.

The Government makes this undertaking: if anything comes out of the New South Wales royal commission report that is worthwhile and should be adopted, we will pick that up as we go. We will not delay this process. Australia cannot wait any longer; we want to get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has waited nine years.

—Senator Campbell says that it has waited long enough. If it has waited long enough, it has waited because the last period of conservative government did nothing about this. We proceeded to sort out industrial relations by dealing with the BLF problem. We have a history of dealing with that, and we are now addressing it. If the Opposition passionately believes that we have waited long enough, it will passionately support the fact that we are moving now and doing something to change.

PARA.TAB: In the end, change will occur in this industry, improvement will occur in this industry, because a framework for change and the possibility of a good outcome are set by the Government, and because the parties in the industry are motivated to make that change. Because of this flat period of trading, because of the need to become more efficient and because of the pressure on infrastructure reform, I believe that change will be possible. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
