—During Question Time I asked Senator Collins whether the Government would consider a request by the Australian Professional Cycling Council for funding in respect of litigation in which it is involved with one Martin Vinnicombe. The Minister advised that the request would be judged on its merits but that thus far no request had been made and that therefore the question was academic. I suspect that Senator Collins had no reason to know this, but my understanding, subsequent to that question and answer, is that a request has been made by that Council and that the litigation starts tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: I make no comment about the substance of the litigation except to say that in the event that Mr Martin Vinnicombe is successful, it means that the price he has paid for cheating on other athletes will be three months suspension. He would be back in the saddle after that and he would escape the penalty which is imposed by the Australian Sports Commission, the Australian Olympic Committee and the Australian Amateur Cycling Association.

I do not purport to be making judgments about the moral conduct of Mr Vinnicombe, but by sheer accident I observed last night on one of the television programs Mr Vinnicombe complaining that perhaps he had just made one small mistake. He wanted to know what price he had to pay for that one small mistake. He was extolling what he had done for Australia. This seemed to be—in my words, not his—a pretty shabby reward for his endeavours.

I stand here on behalf of those athletes who were denied their proper rewards for competing on their merits, for those athletes who chose not to cheat. I think now of some obscure cyclist who, but for the cheating of Mr Martin Vinnicombe, may well have been a silver medallist in Edinburgh. I think of the obscure cyclist, whose name I do not have, who may well have been denied a bronze medal at the Olympic Games in Seoul save for the fact that Mr Martin Vinnicombe defeated him. The life endeavours of an athlete and the ultimate reward are snatched from him by a man now shown—not necessarily on that occasion—to have been prepared to cheat, not only on his own country and on his own supporters but also on the athletes who opposed him in fair and what they thought was open and proper competition.

Perhaps one of the redeeming features of Mr Vinnicombe is that he at least admitted straight up that he was a cheat. But he did not admit that some little time ago. He was asked in an interview in mid-April about the controversy and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Oh, I've had trouble with all different riders all the way through, accusing me of drug taking. If it's not steroids, it's something else.

PARA.TAB: If steroids hadn't been heard of, there would be something else.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is a man who says that this controversy that has dogged him for some time is because of jealous competitors who do not have, in his mind, the same ability as he does. Referring to a matter which has previously been touched upon in this chamber by my colleague Senator Baume, involving a controversy in 1987 regarding a complaint that had been laid against him, he said:

It was in 87 I think. A cyclist in our team reported me for supposedly offering steroids for sale. People quite often look for excuses for their own lack of ability or lack of dedication or whatever. So there had to be an excuse why I'm better than them. If they can blame a small tablet they will. That's the stupid thing about it because all the equipment and all the drugs are available to everyone.

I have read the evidence in that matter and, while I do not make a definitive judgment, on the balance of probability I came to the conclusion that Martin Vinnicombe had sought to sell drugs to Gary Neiwand. Now Mr Vinnicombe tells us that he has been harshly dealt with, yet in April of 1981 he was saying that those who had made the accusations against him were only jealous of him. On the Jana Wendt program, for which he was paid $8,000 for these little pearls, he was asked:
So you are telling me you have never taken steroids before?
Vinnicombe replied:
Yes, that's correct.

He got $8,000 for telling that lie. But perhaps Mr Vinnicombe did not know at that stage that there was a prescription available which was made out on 27 May 1987 by a Dr Daisy Balm for a substance called primabolin. Anybody who knows anything about anabolic steroids knows that primabolin is an anabolic steroid which is used by athletes to enhance their performance and to cheat on their fellow competitors. Mr Vinnicombe now claims that it is unjust that he should be disqualified for two years for cheating in this way. It seems to say something for Mr Vinnicombe that, as I look back at his history, when he was being asked about whether he had any remorse about what he had done to other athletes and what he had done to Australia he said:
Why should I be punished for one stupid f. . . mistake? But hell, had I not been caught and gone on to become world or Olympic champion, people would have been none the wiser.

In other words, had he not been caught he would have been, in his mind, the world champion and the world would have been his oyster. Now he is in litigation. But he was only saying some little time ago—earlier this year, if I recall correctly:
I'm banned from amateur cycling, not professional cycling, so they can get f. . . .

That was the level of remorse Mr Vinnicombe had for the pain and suffering he has brought on not only his own family but also his coach, his supporters, his competitors, his fellow athletes—those he cheated upon—not to mention the taxpayers' funds of which he had been a significant recipient.

PARA.TAB: I should be particularly concerned if I thought that the Australian Professional Cycling Council was unable to litigate this action with Mr Vinnicombe because of a lack of funding and because of what it judges to be his substantial resources in this matter. It would be a grave matter if Mr Vinnicombe were able to get back in the saddle and become a professional cyclist without suffering the same sort of penalty as every other athlete who cheats on his colleagues. I hope that ultimately, if there is funding necessary, it will be made available to the Council to deal with this matter in the way that it ought quite properly be dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the time of the Senate tonight to raise a small matter in relation to the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority, particularly as they relate to safety. On many occasions I have expressed a concern at the direction the Civil Aviation Authority has taken and I do not wish to expand on that tonight beyond reaffirming my position. I think the level of professional expertise within the Department is the lowest it has ever been in modern times.

PARA.TAB: One of my major concerns is about safety. We had the extraordinary situation in the Department of the adoption of a policy of affordable safety as the doctrine for the last two or three years. As an old airman, I simply do not know what affordable safety means. Does it mean that we can afford safety provided that one's wife or one's children are not killed? It is a concept that I do not understand.

What I understand about aviation is that it is one of the most unforgiving of all environments in which human beings operate and that we cannot pay too much attention to the requirements of safety, design, maintenance and operational practices. It has been by relentless pursuit of those objectives that the high safety level has been reached in Australia. The concept that somehow or other we can quantify safety in monetary terms and set a standard of affordable safety is something that is quite alien to me. I do not wish to go down that path tonight.

The relevance of that is that one of the changes that has come to the Department has been the professed belief that officers of the Department are not policemen; they are there as friends and any infringements of operating practice would be met by counselling and education. Last year we approved the introduction of administrative fines, so there was a third barrier introduced before people went to court. We had great assurances from the Minister that the Authority was kind and benevolent and understanding and certainly not there in a hectoring or bullying mode at all.

In two of the recent Bills that have been through this Senate I have raised the matter of the qualifications of inspectors for the CAA. At page 5353 of the Senate Hansard of 21 June last year I made the point that we were giving great powers to inspectors. In the committee stage Senator Collins responded:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, for obvious reasons it—
meaning the CAA—
does not appoint to these positions people who are not suitably qualified.
At page 5354 he went on to say about people who were inspectors for the CAA:
. . . they are investigating breaches of civil aviation regulations and, therefore, they are expert in the aviation field.
Later he said:

PARA.TAB: These people are expert in the areas that they have to implement. But it is unnecessary in this legislation to spell out the qualifications of inspectors as it would be in a police Act . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I know of at least one inspector who, before he got into that position a year or two ago, had no aviation experience at all, yet he was investigating technical breaches of aviation matters. Putting that aside, my concern is this business of how the Department reacts. I received a letter recently from a constituent in Queensland. The letter was written to the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, and it will, in time, be a public document. It reads:
Sir,

I write to inform you of the CAA's actions against me. I am a farmer and was flying over my property when I discovered a group making an illegal stock movement through my property. They had undone the fences to facilitate their movement, they were not on a stock route and had not sought permission. It was a blatant trespass.
I realised I had caught them red handed but from my altitude of 500 ft I could not see who they were. So I descended and made a low pass to have a look.

I went to the police who said that the law of trespass was full of holes and there was little I could do. The trespassers complained to the CAA and now I have a summons for flying below 500 ft. Where is the justice in the system? It was suggested by my local member of parliament that if I had witnessed a murder being committed and flew below 500 ft to try and stop or apprehend somebody, would the CAA treat me in a similar way.
Yours sincerely,
Norman Brown

I find that absolutely astonishing. We have a farmer flying over his own land; he sees a group of stock illegally on his property—permission has not been sought. He sees that fences are down. What would any normal human being do? If that happens over my property and I am flying over it, I will certainly do everything within my powers to determine what is going on and take whatever actions I find appropriate to apprehend those people. I find that astonishing.

PARA.TAB: It is worse than that. The Civil Aviation inspector came out to his property and said, `We've got a few little questions we would like to ask you—nothing serious'. The farmer said, `That's fine. Come in, have a cup of tea'. So they sat down and they spent hours talking about it. The farmer told the inspector precisely what he had done and what the circumstances were. In other words, he incriminated himself. It would have been quite possible for the farmer to say, `I don't know anything about the incident; I am not prepared to discuss it'. Then it would have been up to the people illegally moving through his property to somehow establish that he was below 500 feet. He could have claimed that since it was his own land he would have been legally entitled to land on it and that his pass was an approach for a precautionary landing or something like that. He could have covered himself in a thousand different ways, but being an honest person he just told the truth. His thanks for that is to have a summons dropped on him by the Civil Aviation Authority.

That incident does nothing at all to encourage air safety. It does nothing to encourage people to be frank and open with the Department when they have problems. This man has had 18 years of flying experience. He has had no brushes with the CAA, no infringements, no breaches of the law at all. I find it quite extraordinary that that should happen.

The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association had a matter of concern in relation to the stated policy of the Civil Aviation Authority. On 16 August 1991 it received a letter from Mr Ron Cooper, the general manager of safety and regulation standards. It had made an inquiry as to what procedures—this was in advance of the farmer's incident—would be followed by the Department in the case of breaches of the law. The reply of one paragraph by Mr Cooper to AOPA says:

SPEECH.PARA: Your recollection of my words is correct and we will be following the sequential process of education, counselling, administrative fines, prosecutions.

There from the man who is in charge of the Department is reaffirmation of the policy the CAA and the Government have given us on the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority. I support that policy. I think it is wise to talk to people and tell them where they have gone wrong, to counsel them so that they do not make mistakes. Most of these mistakes are generally made out of innocence or ignorance; they are not done intentionally.

PARA.TAB: Then we have this facility of fining, which is something like a traffic fine. The Government introduced that last year. Finally, we take them to court, which is a last resort. This was not followed in this case. I bring it to the attention of the Senate tonight because I do not think it aids the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority to have that sort of incident occurring in its name. I do not think it aids the advancement of safe operating practices in the country when someone is persecuted in the way this man is going to be because he was obviously concerned about his farm and his own stock.
It is very hard to make a living off the land at present. One of the notoriously sensitive areas to any cattle owner, as Senator Brownhill would know, is the matter of cattle

SPEECH.PARA: theft. We would well imagine the consternation of this farmer when he looked over the side of his aircraft, saw a mob of cattle on his property and fences down and wondered what the devil was happening.

PARA.TAB: I advised the Minister that I would be saying something about the Civil Aviation Authority. I hope that in due course he will take a very firm line with those people in the Civil Aviation Authority who laid charges here. When the Civil Aviation Authority was contacted its very lame excuse was, `It's all too late. We're very sorry, but it's now in the courts and there's nothing we can do about it'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the entitlements to self-drive motor vehicles and Z-cars of (a) Ministers; and (b) public servants.
(2) Is there any difference in the entitlements between (a) parliamentary weeks; (b) weekends; and (c) other times.
(3) What is the extent, both in numbers and monetary terms, of the fleet of self-drive and Z-cars operated by the Department of Administrative Services and/or the Transport and Storage Group.

(4) When self-drive or Z-cars are being used by Ministers and public servants, what charges are raised, against whom are such charges raised and what is the hourly, daily and weekly rate of the charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Ministers are eligible to be provided with a State registered Commonwealth owned motor vehicle in accordance with Determination Number 34 of 1990 of the Remuneration Tribunal. The determination provides all Senators and Members with the option of being provided with a vehicle for parliamentary, electorate and private use.
A Minister may also use a self-drive vehicle for official purposes in situations where scheduled commercial services or car-with-driver services do not adequately meet the Minister's requirements.

(b) Public servants who are SES officers or equivalent can use a State registered Commonwealth vehicle for limited private use subject to payment of a contribution. Apart from private use by an eligible officer, the vehicles are used for official purposes. Z-plated vehicles are only available for official use including garaging at residences where this is in the Commonwealth's interest.
(3) Currently the Department of Administrative Services has more than 17,000 vehicles worth around $250 million under the management of DAS FLEET.
(4) DAS FLEET establishes charges to recover all costs from its clients. The rates of charge are dependent upon the type of service requested.

Hire charges for self-drive vehicles used by Ministers for official purposes are met by their home department. Costs for Commonwealth owned, private plated vehicles provided to Ministers in accordance with Remuneration Tribunal Determination No. 34 of 1990 are met by the Parliamentary and Ministerial Services Branch of the Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) For each special purpose flight authorised by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, since 1 January 1990, what was (a) the total cost of the flight; (b) the total cost of all beverages consumed on the flight; (c) the total cost of all food consumed on the flight; (d) the total catering cost for the flight; and (e) the stated purpose for the flight.
(2) What has been the total cost of all special purpose flights authorised by Senator Richardson since 1 January 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: On Tuesday 3 September 1991, I indicated to Senator Alston that it was not possible to provide specific answers at that time. I undertook to provide an accurate answer after the Defence Inspector General had examined the manner in which catering for VIP flights is conducted and reported to me. I have now received the Inspector General's report.

The general principles applying to existing procedures for VIP flights and their associated reporting reflects decisions taken by the Holt Government in 1967 and supported since by successive Governments.
The cost of VIP flights is reviewed annually by the RAAF as a basis for recovering catering and running costs on an aggregate basis for all VIP flights.
The Inspector General's report found that accounting arrangements for catering costs do not permit accurate attribution of those costs to each individual VIP flight.

The present practices have been relatively simple to apply and form a reasonable basis upon which to allocate funding responsibility for VIP flights between Defence and other Departments. The existing procedures continue to meet this specific objective and for this reason I do not propose to change them.
The Inspector General identified some minor deficiencies where adherence to present procedures could be improved and I have directed that those deficiencies be remedied.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following information from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Fuel is purchased and resold to any company requiring fuel at the Oombulgurri airstrip.

(3) The intent of the question is not clear. It is presumed the Oombi Association should be Oombulgurri and that the question relates to upgrade of the airstrip. (5) Within the 1990-91 budget for Oombulgurri Association, an amount of $31,200 was spent on air charter expenses for legitimate council and community business. As an incorporated entity the Oombulgurri Association has a Constitution which outlines controls placed on its operations by its members. In turn, ATSIC Regional Councils review spending by Aboriginal organisations within their region.
(6) In 1987-88, Balgo Hills Aboriginal Corporation, on behalf of Kingfisher Aviation, received a loan of $50,000 from the Aboriginal Development Commission. The term of the loan was ten years.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the function of the Multi-Function Agency Processing System (MAPS) used in Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices and, particularly, what is the function in relation to payments of the Formal Training Allowance.
(2) When was the MAPS system first installed and what has been the cost to date of its installation.
(3) Why was the installation of MAPS deemed necessary and what improvements to the functioning of the CES network are expected to arise from its installation.
(4) On what basis was the decision made to install MAPS.
(5) What trials occurred before the decision was made to install MAPS to ascertain its appropriateness for use by the CES.
(6) Have there been reports from any and which CES offices of problems experienced so far with the use of MAPS and what are the nature of those problems.
(7) From where is the MAPS system centrally administered and what facilities have been provided for CES offices to report user problems with the MAPS system and to have those problems solved.
(8) Do all CES offices have access to the MAPS system; if not, what categories of offices do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Multiple Agency Processing System (MAPS) is a Department of Social Security (DSS) computer system. Its function is to pay Formal Training Assistance (FTA) to some participants in formal training courses approved through Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) labour market programs.

FTA consists of a living component, equivalent to a participant's entitlement to Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance (JSA/NSA), a training component ($30 per week for full-time trainees over 21 years and sole parents) and ancillary allowances such as Fares, Living-Away-From-Home Allowance and compulsory course costs.

MAPS pays the FTA training component and ancillary allowances to those trainees who are not in receipt of JSA/NSA, for example pensioners. Currently, part-time trainees who do receive JSA/NSA are also paid their FTA training component and ancillary allowances through MAPS; however, this group will be paid through the DSS Newstart system in the near future. MAPS only pays the $30 training component and ancillary allowances. MAPS clients continue to receive their general income support through normal means; for example pensioners continue to receive their pensions from the DSS Pension system.

(2) MAPS makes FTA payments in response to client data input from DEET's MAPS Data Input Unit (MDIU). The MDIU receives this data from claim forms sent to it by CES offices. The MDIU commenced operation early in July 1991. As of January 1992, DEET has spent some $24,000 to establish and operate the MDIU, excluding salaries, whilst DSS has spent $36,500 on the development of MAPS and a further $24,500 in ongoing maintenance and enhancement.

(3) The previous system of payment of FTA became redundant with the incorporation of FTA payments in Job Search and Newstart Allowances from 1 July 1991. The MAPS system was developed for FTA clients not in receipt of JSA or NSA.

(4) DSS's Newstart system was established in July 1991 to pay JSA/NSA. FTA recipients in receipt of JSA/NSA are paid their entitlements via the Newstart system. Non-JSA/NSA clients and part-time trainees (that is MAPS clients) could not be paid by the Newstart system without costly system re-development. This re-development could not be justified considering the small group of clients involved. MAPS was developed to pay FTA to these clients.

(5) Before 1 July 1991, all FTA recipients had their claims processed in a way similar to the current MAPS system through DSS Central Benefits Offices located in capital cities. The great majority of FTA recipients, who are in receipt of JSA/NSA, now have their claims processed via an electronic interface between CES offices and DSS regional offices. This innovation has resulted in a major reduction in payment delays and problems for the large majority of FTA clients. As substantial changes to the method of payment of FTA to nonJSA/NSA clients were not made, extensive system trialling was not necessary. The MAPS computer system has operated effectively since its introduction, and has been free of any substantial technical misfunction.

(6) All FTA recipients not in receipt of JSA/ NSA, who were in training as of 1 July 1991 were transferred electronically by DSS to the MAPS system. A number of FTA trainees did not appear as current clients on DSS's system at the time of transfer and therefore their records were suspended, causing payment delays. In addition, since then, there have been reports of payment delays, generally caused by inaccurate provision of financial institution codes, tax file numbers, and bank account numbers by clients on their FTA claim forms as well as some miscoding by CES staff.
A review was undertaken of MAPS procedures during the first month of its operation which identified these problems and methods to alleviate them. Remedial action taken to date includes:
revised MAPS administrative procedures;
MAPS system enhancements; and
increased MDIU resources.
The implementation of this remedial action has resulted in a substantial decrease in both the number and duration of payment delays.

(7) The MDIU situated in Milton, Queensland enters data from claim forms sent to it by CES offices and provides this data electronically to the DSS Brisbane computer system, which makes direct credit payments to clients' accounts. CES officers have access to the MDIU via four telephone lines, as well as by facsimile. An alternative contact for CES officers is the Central Office FTA administration section based in Canberra.
(8) Access to the MAPS computer program is not available to the CES network. All CES offices send claim forms to the MDIU for processing through the MAPS data entry system.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the ruling that only 50 per cent of a standard refund is payable for the lesser of two procedures performed during one operation based on the assumption that doctors will charge 50 per cent of normal fees for a second procedure and 25 per cent for a third; if so, what evidence does Medicare have that this charging agenda is the standard practice of medical practitioners.
(2) Is there any means by which claimants who have been charged in full for second and subsequent procedures can obtain a full refund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The fees and Medicare benefits applicable for an operation which consists of two or more surgical procedures carried out by the one surgeon (or more than one surgeon where they assist each other) and performed on a patient on the one occasion are calculated according to the `multiple operation formula'. That is, the Schedule fee for the second and subsequent procedures are discounted by 50 and 75 per cent respectively and Medicare benefits are then assessed on the aggregate of the fees.
Section 15 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 specifies the multiple operation provisions. This legislative requirement has been part of the health insurance arrangements since 1953.
The reduction in the fee for the second and subsequent procedures takes account of a number of

ANSWER.PARA: factors. Although the actual operating time for each procedure may be the same, there would be no additional time involved for the surgeon in arranging and preparing for surgery, and such procedures would have a common after-care period.

PARA.TAB: It is felt that the Medicare Benefits Schedule fee structure, of which this rule is a component part, reflects a reasonable return for surgical services. It is relevant that the Australian Medical Association also advocates the application of the multiple operation rule in its List of Medical Services and Fees.
